This is an attack not only on rural Canada but also on the 3,000 or so postal employees who lost their jobs. Canada Post says that the purpose is to reduce the corporation's costs and improve customer service. The facts contradict this.

Mr. Speaker, one in every 10 Canadian women will receive during her lifetime the devastating diagnosis of breast cancer. More than 14,000 women will be so diagnosed this year alone. Half of those diagnosed will die from it. It is the leading killer of Canadian women aged 35 to 54.
In spite of these figures, the incidence and survival rate for breast cancer have remained relatively unchanged for the past 20 to 30 years. The subcommittee of this House on the status of women reported: "There are big gaps in knowledge about breast cancer, the causes, the solutions, the appropriate treatment. This lack of knowledge exacts a price which is far too great".
This government has said that it will soon be announcing major spending cuts. On the eve of these cuts, I urge that more, not fewer, resources be devoted to the prevention, detection, cure and ultimate elimination of the disease breast cancer.

As the Auditor General admitted himself, there is no easy solution to some of these problems. However, he
stressed the need for a better understanding of their impact and for taking constructive measures to deal with them.
I would like to read to you what he said in the first paragraph of his introduction, and I quote: "For several years now, Canada has experienced slow economic growth, business closures and high unemployment. Canada is not unique: other industrialized nations have experienced similar downturns. As Auditor General, and as a Canadian, I am deeply concerned about the economic challenges Canada faces both nationally and internationally, and about their impact on individual Canadians. Canadians are very worried about the impact of annual deficits and the accumulated debt on their standard of living and that of future generations of Canadians. At the same time, they expect the government to provide more, not fewer, services. The government's dilemma, which is not really new, is that its financial resources are constrained, while demands on those resources increase".
The Auditor General is the government's watchdog for the administration of our public finances, and that is as it should be.

I quote from the June 1992 United Nations report on methyl bromide and the ozone layer: "scientists and governments have also identified methyl bromide as the major contributor to stratospheric bromine. Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, the Competition Act demands that merchants sell goods at advertised prices. Yet right across this country merchants today are advertising goods, knowing that there are taxes and other charges ranging from the GST, the PST to the gas guzzler tax and the tire tax and other taxes and charges that materially affect the ultimate price of the product.
This advertising of products is deceitful and almost bordering on the fraudulent.
I call upon the government to immediately produce amendments to the Competition Act to force merchants to sell goods at the advertised price unless the ad specifically sets out that the price is plus taxes and charges and sets out exactly what those taxes and charges are.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the report of the Auditor General has given the government a failing grade in preparing Canadians for the event of an emergency.
Since 1987 the Auditor General has been calling for improvements to Canada's Emergency Response Plan. Five years later, we see that longstanding problems in federal emergency planning have not been addressed.
The proposed national earthquake plan is still not complete. There has been no follow-up on the recommendations of the 1986 report on the Bhopal chemical disaster. A review on the Chernobyl nuclear disaster recommending major improvements to Canada's nuclear emergency response plan has been virtually ignored.
Last year, a number of my B.C. colleagues and I visited the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington just south of the B.C. border. We learned that the Canadian government had failed to develop adequate co-ordinated emergency response measures in the event of a chemical or nuclear explosion at Hanford which could affect B.C. communities.
The Auditor General's report is vindication that my colleagues and I were right. Canada is not adequately prepared in the case of accident or disaster, be it nuclear, chemical or natural.

Mr. Speaker, with virtually all sectors in Canada the cultural community is experiencing severe financial, pressures.
In fact, in many budgets, both public and private, contributions to the arts have become the most tempting targets to cut. Unfortunately, the threshold of cultural funding is already too low for survival in many instances and a number of Canadian institutions, both large and small, are now in serious jeopardy. As they are compelled to close their doors, there will be a special kind of pain to this recession.
As budget priorities are reordered, we must not too quickly forget that the performing arts, the cultural industries and indeed even the CBC are among the most important ties that bind our country together.
Neither should we neglect the reality that culture is an area of significant potential for economic growth representing close to 3 per cent of our gross domestic product and growing as an important export industry.
It should also be remembered that the cultural threshold is so low to begin with that even marginal increases in cultural investments will pay disproportionately high dividends in terms of public spirit and economic return.

In the past three weeks, interest rates have increased nearly three percentage points and the consequences are very obvious. business people with whom they are competing in the United States.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I share the view of the hon. Leader of the Opposition that high interest rates are certainly having a dampening effect upon the economy and economic recovery.
I also point out to him that in order to maintain low interest rates over the long term we have to get at the fundamentals. That is essentially to bring inflation down and to keep it down. That has been one of our primary objectives.
There are concerns as a result of the volatility in the exchange market and indeed concerns in the financial market with respect to those who hold Canadian bonds and bills. There is a degree of concern as a result of the referendum. There is concern about the extent of the deficits, both at the federal and provincial levels. There is concern over the current account deficit.
This has all been focused on, particularly as a result of the focus which has been placed in Europe with respect to the United Kingdom, with respect to France, with respect to Italy and a number of other industrialized nations.
Really what is happening is that market forces are forcing up interest rates, and I think the hon. member understands that.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
Last night on the Fifth Estate we saw the horrors in Brazilian jails. Military police invaded the prison with guard dogs. The police fired over 5,000 shots leaving 238 prisoners dead. The threat of death and violence hangs over Christine Lamont and David Spencer every day.
The minister said yesterday that Brazil may not expel, but just this year a Chilean prisoner was sent home under an expulsion order. Why will the minister not request the expulsion of David and Christine?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the term expulsion is used to apply to a lot of things in Brazil that have nothing to do with expulsion as the hon. member understands it.
The Chilean who was expelled from Brazil was actually extradited. Our understanding of the term is that he was extradited home to stand trial for offences that he had committed in Chile. He was not expelled under the provision that is being looked for or that would be said to apply under these conditions. It is actually an extradition.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question.
Premier McKenna said last night that he was very concerned about the safety of Christine and David and he characterized the judgment as extraordinarily callous and cruel. The Prime Minister has said that he was profoundly troubled by this case.
Canada is known world-wide for its compassion. Will the government honour the Prime Minister's commitment to Premier McKenna and compassionately request the expulsion order to bring them home?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have all expressed our concern about the length and severity of the sentence that was applied to Mr. Spencer and Ms. Lamont. I have said so myself. I think the sentence is excessive.
That is why we look to the appeals that we believe are about to be heard on the length of the sentence; and we are looking forward to seeing the results of this in the very short term. We are hoping those sentences will be reduced as a result.

Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the Minister of National Defence, I will direct my question to the associate minister of defence or the Secretary of State for External Affairs. I have given notice of the question.
In view of the dirge of bad news out of former Yugoslavia this might be a glimmer of some hope to a good many people still there. I have a letter from a constituent whose grandson is a sergeant with the peacekeeping force in Yugoslavia. He wrote to his grandmother who happened to be a constituent of mine.
As a result church groups in my area collected over two tonnes of used clothing. Through the bureaucracy of the Red Cross and Defence there does not seem to be any way to get this material to Belleville, hopefully to get it over there to help some of the children caught in that quagmire.
As a matter of humanitarian need, I am just asking them to break through the bureaucracy. At least one of the ministers could get a co-ordinator to find out how best this could be done. I understand this spontaneous grass-roots interest of citizens to help is spreading to many churches in Atlantic Canada. There is more than two tonnes of used material and clothing right now in one church alone.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have stated in this House before that the policy of the government in terms of humanitarian assistance overseas is that we urge Canadians who wish to help, and we know that many Canadians do, to work with the international agencies in the position to assess needs in the region and the uses to which things can be put. We urge them to work with agencies like the International Red Cross and other organizations.
We do not have the capacity as a government to provide transport for the goods that people choose to send. I have warned Canadians before-and I would ask the hon. member to pass this on to his constituents and to his church groups-that international organizations are not in a position to use much of what is being
Oral Questions
collected. There are very particular needs; they have to be co-ordinated. Indeed we have hard evidence of goods having been collected and shipped to other parts of the world that have not been able to use them.
It is such a disappointment, I know, to those who want to give, but it is far better to work with the international organizations. I have a pamphlet on this that I would be prepared to give the hon. member for his groups.

Mr. Speaker, I understand the minister's answer in part and I appreciate the bureaucracy involved.
My constituent, this 80-year old grandmother, Reverend Vaughan of the church and other churches have been in touch with the International Red Cross that has told them, much to my amazement, that the International Red Cross would help if it were money or if it were new clothing.
Surely used clothing in the horror of Bosnia, Croatia, and all the other places over there including Yugoslavia, could be of some help since we do have transport going over there from time to time. It might help to have at least some officer either in Defence or in External Affairs to be the co-ordinator to talk to the citizens of Canada and tell them the answer, that there is no hope or they might be able to do something rather than meet the stone wall they have met until now.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: We will get on to the answer, if the minister wishes to answer.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is not the bureaucracy. This is the result of careful planning in which those of us at the political level have been involved.
I had asked my department to look at all the ways and bring all the imagination that it could to how we could best help. Through working with international agencies the conclusion we have come to, not once but many times as we were examining this issue, was that we had to assist the international agencies in the way they advise us and they advise what is the most appropriate.
We do not have free transport or free space in transport going over. When our planes and our transport

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to rise today on behalf of a large number of British Columbians who petition this House concerning Bill C-91 which seeks to end the licensing of further noname generic drugs at an additional cost of at least $1 billion a year to Canadians.
Since the price of both new and existing drugs has already increased substantially to individuals, provincial and private drug plans since 1987 when Bill C-22 allowed up to a 10-year period of no generic competition, the petitioners pray to this House not to proceed with Bill C-91 and repeal Bill C-22.

Mr. Speaker, I have a petition from a number of people from the west coast of Canada. They draw to the attention of the House the fact that the United States has unfairly imposed a duty on our softwood lumber exports to that country, and has engaged in numerous other trade practices which amount to harassment of Canadian producers.
The petitioners also note that the free trade agreement between Canada and the United States has resulted in lost jobs and devastation to the Canadian economy while not providing the promised benefits.
The petitioners therefore call upon Parliament to request that the Prime Minister and the Minister for International Trade take any necessary action to defend the interests of the Canadian softwood lumber industry against the unfair duty. They also request that Parliament act immediately to effect the cancellation of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement.

Mr. Speaker, I have two petitions to file pursuant to Standing Order 36.
The first petition points out that family-class and assisted-relatives historically have been an important part of Canadian immigration and that family-class and assisted-relatives have people in Canada to help them find employment, housing and learn Canadian customs and language.

Routine Proceedings
The petitioners pray that the government undertake a change in policy direction that will give family-class and assisted-relatives first priority in immigration.

Mr. Speaker, my second petition points out that 75 per cent of all services in the immigration office in New Delhi are from people seeking assistance from the Punjab. They point out that it is very difficult for people to travel from the Punjab to New Delhi.
The petitioners call upon the government to immediately open a new Canadian consular service in the Punjab to provide not only immigration services but services for visitors' visas.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I have the honour and the privilege to present a petition on behalf of hundreds of Albertans, many of whom live in my riding in places like Sherwood Park, New Sarepta, Beaumont and South Cooking Lake.
The petitioners ask that Parliament review the laws of Canada to replace the Young Offenders Act with an updated Juvenile Delinquents Act with a lowered maximum age of 13 years.

Madam Speaker, I have another petition today on the Court Challenges Program which, as we know, was abolished by this government.
The petitioners urge the government to restore this program, and as of yesterday they are supported by a report from the Commissioner of Official Languages which shows the significant achievements of the program and the effect that abolishing it has on linguistic minorities. The Commissioner of Official Languages and the signers of this petition recommend that the government find a way to make it easier for Canadians to defend their constitutional rights in court, because it is fundamental in a democracy to be able to go to court. Thousands of people like these have already signed this kind of petition. I therefore ask the government to act as soon as possible.

Madam Speaker, I rise to present a petition signed by many hundreds of people from Winnipeg who join many hundreds of thousands of Canadians in their concern about Bill C-91, which is now being fought in committee.
These petitioners ask Parliament to not proceed with Bill C-91 and to repeal Bill C-22, which was passed in 1987, so that Canadians will have the full benefit from lower priced generic drugs and so that provincial and private drug plans can serve Canadians without being forced to charge higher fees and provide less coverage.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure to rise in this House once again to present more petitions regarding the murder of Nina de Villiers and containing suggestions by many of my constituents that the justice system in Canada be changed.
These petitioners believe that crimes of violence against the person are intolerable and that they are the most abhorrent crimes facing society. The petitioners are asking that sentencing in crimes of violence more appropriately reflect our society's abhorrence of violence in order to act as a true deterrent.
They also point out that too often the risk to society posed by the early release of a violent offender appears to be a secondary consideration to the rights of the individual criminal. These petitioners are from many communities in my riding and are added to the thousands of constituents who have already raised their voices on this important issue.

Madam Speaker, I have a petition requesting that the goods and services tax on books and reading materials be removed. These petitioners point out that literacy is a cornerstone of a democratic society. It contributes to productivity and competitiveness, which are clearly objectives of Canada.
These petitioners ask that this tax on books be reviewed and, if at all possible, eliminated immediately.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to table a petition from people in Val-d'Or, Abitibi. The signers say that violent movies on television are dangerous and therefore unacceptable because they incite violence.
They say that all toys that incite violent games are unacceptable and should not be made. They also say that the freedom of the press to report acts of violence should be limited and information on violent acts that is repeated too often on all television stations and on radio can incite others to commit the same acts of violence.
Therefore the petitioners humbly ask Parliament to legislate on the above-mentioned points to eliminate violence in our society in order to protect our children more and give all our fellow citizens a better quality of life.

Madam Speaker, I have a number of petitions from signatories throughout my riding presented in conjunction with a number of petitions throughout the province of British Columbia.
These petitioners are concerned about a project proposed by Multinational Resources which intends to dam a portion of the flow of the North Thompson River and divert that water into the California market.
The petitioners are concerned about the export of Canadian waters. They have urged the Government of Canada to state categorically that it will not permit our freshwater rivers to be dammed or diverted into the United States and to state that our Canadian rivers are not for sale.

Madam Speaker, I would like to present a petition signed by more than
1,000	residents of Calgary in memory of Ryan Garrioch.
These petitioners draw the attention of Parliament to the following: That the majority of Canadians support equal treatment of criminal offenders but with legislative age shelters from criminal law for very young adolescents; that chapter 15 of the Charter of Rights guarantees the equality of rights.
Therefore your petitioners request that Parliament revise the laws of Canada to replace the Young Offenders Act with an updated Juvenile Delinquents Act with a lowered minimum age of 13 years.

Madam Speaker, it is my honour to present a petition signed by hundreds of people from Nova Scotia to B.C., including many from my own riding. These people believe that we do not know enough about aboriginal cultures in this country and that we do not give enough recognition to their diversity and strength.
Therefore they are calling on Parliament to enact Bill C-268, an act respecting a national solidarity day for the First Nations of Canada. This would be a day of recognition of Canada's original inhabitants, a day on which to honour their native cultures. It would take place on June 21 of each year.

speechtext:
Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-63 be amended in Clause 1 by adding immediately after line 16 at page 1, the following:
"(3) The Minister of Employment and Immigration shall
(a) identify property, including intellectual property, data bases, models or library materials, that were created or acquired by the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council in the fulfilment of its mandate and that have a capital or commercial value; and
(ib) transfer that property, with or without valuable consideration, to a federal, provincial or non-governmental body to be used to pursue that body's mandate."
He said: Madam Speaker, I congratulate you on your grouping of the motions for debate. There is a certain mathematical symmetry in how the motions have been grouped now. That will probably make it easier for us
here in the House. But mathematical symmetry is not what we are dealing with in this government bill this afternoon.
The particular motion we are dealing with identifies what I believe is a gap in the government's treatment of the way in which agencies and Crown corporations are dissolved and dispensed with, privatized. It is not immediately apparent why the government has failed to give attention to this.
One could accept that over the last dozen years or so there has been some initiative to reduce the size of government and make it more efficient, to privatize areas of activity that are perhaps more appropriately dealt with in the private sector and the business sector.
In developing the field, the lexicon and the procedure of privatization and dissolution, I am not so sure we have it right yet.
The amendments take note of the fact that there will likely have been-I would be very shocked if it had not occurred-a development within the agency, here the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, of a certain amount of knowledge and expertise. Some may call it intellectual property, which was often referred to in the committee hearings, but computer-stored data and information, all of which was relevant to the original existing mandate of the agency. When the agency was about to be dissolved, no one gave much thought to the value, if any, of the accumulated expertise, intellectual property, data bases, and information libraries of the particular agency.
What often happens in the private sector when a business goes down is that the ownership interest departs, locks the doors-maybe they do not even lock the doors. Suddenly, the scavengers, the vultures, the auctioneers and those who work in the field of bankruptcy swoop down, scoop up and take away. They sell the stuff for the best price they can get, but it is often at a fraction of the original market value of these things.
In this particular case the government is dissolving an agency that it feels no longer can serve a good public policy purpose. While some of our colleagues opposite are convinced that it can no longer fill the purpose and that other agencies can, the government is going to proceed. I believe the government has not taken account of just what assets there were in this category and how
November 25, 1992

the government proposes to protect them. Certainly we would not want to see them destroyed.
I want to point out in this particular case, as I will point out in relation to some of these other agencies as we debate this bill today and tomorrow, we must take note of the stark reality that the government has already dissolved and liquidated the agency.
There is something that does not ring quite right about that. I had an assistant attempt to locate these agencies on the map, by telephone, by fax machine, and we have come up with precious little. I am puzzled when the law clearly requires a statute of this House to dissolve and liquidate an agency like this how it is that the agency, as I speak now, has already disappeared off the map.
As we make what I believe to be a constructive proposal here in disposal of the assets, maybe it is all for naught. Maybe the government has gone ahead of its authority to do so and dissolved the agency and liquidated it. Maybe what we are doing in this House just does not matter any more. I feel I have to note whether what the government has done or not done is legal or illegal.
In any event, the debate on this must be here if for no other reason than to lay constructive groundwork for dissolutions and privatizations in the year to come because undoubtedly there will be some no matter what government is in power. When we do it, we want to do it right.
To recap, this particular amendment would require, by statute-not just by policy or by someone's good judgment in the department-that the minister responsible for the agency identifies property including intellectual property, data bases, models, library materials, et cetera, that were required and developed in the course of the agency's mandate. The minister will protect them, keep them together and transfer them to a successor agency or the ministry involved. In that way they would be protected as an asset and would continue to serve the public in the domain for which they were originally created.

Madam Speaker, I would like to speak just briefly to this particular section.
Government Orders
I echo the words of my colleague with respect to the divisions that have been made concerning the remaining motions. With respect to this particular agency however, the Canadian Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the position that we took in committee and here in the House on second reading was that it did seem to us that this was an agency which could be replaced. Its work was in fact being done by other agencies within the government and it therefore was not serving a function for which the money contributed by taxpayers represented a valuable contribution and a valuable return to those taxpayers.
For that reason, it seems to us that to transfer the property associated with the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council to other federal, provincial or non-governmental bodies is questionable.
I look, for instance, at something like the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre. It seems to me that they are handling much of the work which the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council was looking at. To continue therefore with this particular council's activities would represent, in our view, a waste of taxpayers' resources at a time when those taxpayers' resources need to be marshalled as carefully as possible to achieve the wider social and political objectives that we have in our economy.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to speak on this motion concerning Bill C-63. This motion talks about the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, which was created in 1977 to advise the Minister of Employment and Immigration of the time about the department's policies and programs.
You will understand that since 1977, this function has been replaced with a much broader consultation structure in the Canadian Labour Force Development Board. The council costs the federal government $200,000 a year. The government decided that the Department of Employment and Immigration, with what is now in place, no longer specifically needed the council and that is why it is being abolished. This will save Canadian taxpayers $200,000 a year. I think that is important.

Government Orders
Madam Speaker, you must understand that legally, the boards and commissions mentioned in Bill C-63 continue to exist, as legal entities, but they no longer have any money to spend. Therefore they no longer cost the federal government anything. That is what you must understand: the board still exists as a legal entity and there is no reason to believe, as my colleague would suggest, that Parliament has acted illegally by ending these boards before Parliament has decided the issue, because they continue to exist, legally.
As for all the assets and property of the various boards and commissions to be discussed this afternoon, a plan was submitted to Treasury Board which approved the liquidation or transfer of these various goods and services to already existing federal agencies or departments. All the intellectual property, as mentioned in the motion, and other assets are already transferred to some department or other. In the case ot the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, it is transferred to the department; in the other case, it will be transferred to the National Library, the National Archives, et cetera. Everything is being done to ensure that all the data and other resources in these various boards and commissions remain for the needs of the Canadian government and at the same time Canadian taxpayers can save money by closing and abolishing some councils.
This is how it has to be looked at. In closing, let me point out that since all that is now in place and Treasury Board has already made the necessary arrangements, I think that many of the motions before us are not applicable since the work they ask us to do has already been done.
Therefore I hope that Bill C-63 will be passed as soon as possible.

He said: Madam Speaker, this particular piece of legislation carries through the government's intention of eliminating a number of important institutions and agencies which have provided valuable assistance to Canadian policymakers and valuable ideas to the Cana-
November 25, 1992

dian public in the period since they were variously established.
The particular set of amendments we are dealing with at the moment attempts to restore to the legislation and therefore to restore to life the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
We heard testimony about a great many of these institutions as we went through this bill in committee earlier this year. Frankly, the case for some of the institutions, as I suggested with the Advisory Committee on Employment and Immigration, was not strong. However, the case for this particular institution was especially strong. This is partly because this was one of the most recent institutions to be established. It was established by legislation in 1983. This was an institution which reflected and represented, to the Canadian public and to policymakers in the government, some of the newer thinking in foreign policy debate and consideration throughout the world. It was not an institution which reflected the old-style belief that that you could somehow maintain peace through massive arms build-ups and through the philosophy of the deterrence. It was not, on the other hand, an institution which took the polar opposite position of saying that the solution is complete disarmament.
Instead, this was an institution which sought through collective co-operation and collective security to establish a new approach to our thinking about international affairs. It was an institution which operated very successfully and at a very limited cost to the federal government. A measure of its success is the tremendous list of names of people who were in touch with the legislative committee that looked at this piece of legislation. They tried to persuade the committee that this was at least one institution that should be maintained because of innovative approach, its thoughtfulness and its excellent leadership.
I could go through the many names of Canadians who wrote to the committee. It is perhaps even more interesting to recognize the international reputation which CIIPS, as the Canadian Institute of International Peace and Security came to be called, had managed to establish throughout the world.
Government Orders
We received letters and representations to maintain this institution from the Brookings Institution in the United States, ABC News in the United States, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, the Congressional Research Service, various representatives from the faculty of Harvard University, the Centre for Science and International Affairs at Harvard University, Princeton University's Department of Psychology, the United Nations Development Program, the U.S. Institute for Peace, and the University of Michigan. Outside the United States we received representations from a great many Canadian institutions and from a great many international institutions.
Some of those international institutions that were in touch with the committee included the University of Southampton in the U.K., Western Australian Health Promotion Foundation, the Asian Peace Research Institution, the German Society for Foreign Affairs, the National Institute for Research Advancement in Japan, SIPRI in Sweden-which is one of the foremost institutions dealing with international peace, and the United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research. I could list a vast number of institutions.
The arguments which many of them put forward are perhaps best summarized in a letter which I have received from the Department of Political Science at the University of Windsor in my own home area. Let me just read this into the record if I could: "We are shocked and dismayed," the writers of this letter indicate, "by the government's announced intention of disbanding the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. If Canada is to have an effective voice in this time of new alignments and unexpected problems on the world scene it can only be based on independent research of high quality done from a Canadian perspective".
The writers of the letter went on to say: "The Department of External Affairs by its nature is not well equipped to do research designed to find innovative solutions to unprecedented problems. We would therefore urge your committee to oppose rescinding the existing legislation which created CUPS and to urge the government to provide it with funding as the legislation provides".
I would like to quote from the institute's original act: "Increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective with particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution".

In pursuit of that to: "(a) foster, fund and conduct research on matters relating to international peace and security; (b) promote scholarship in matters relating to international peace and security; (c) study and propose ideas and policies for the enhancement of international peace and security; and (d) collect and disseminate information on and encourage public discussion of issues of international peace and security".
It is especially important in our changing international context that we have an institute that can create the possibility of promoting discussion and debate among the public about international peace and security. It is especially important that we have new approaches to collective international security being discussed, studied and debated in this country.
It is especially important that we in Canada have new approaches to some of the age old questions that our Department of External Affairs has looked at. It is especially important that we bring into this debate and permit to contribute to this debate some of the younger scholars, some of the newer approaches, and some of the more innovative institutions throughout our country. That is what CUPS did. It reached out to new people, it reached out to new ways of thinking, and it reached out to the public in a way, frankly, that the Department of External Affairs does not do.
This was a valuable institution. It was an institution led by people who, when they talked to the committee, were most impressive in terms of their concern about getting value for the money for the taxpayers of Canada.
I regret very much that the government has chosen to wind up this institution. I therefore urge the House to support this series of amendments by taking out of this bill the points dealing with the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. That would see to it that CUPS would continue as an institution able to give good service to the people of this country.

Madam Speaker, in speaking to this series of amendments that the member from Essex has put forward, which are similar to those which I introduced, I would like members for a moment to think about what they saw on the news last evening or what they read in their papers this
morning: major questions about our peacekeepers in Bosnia-Hercegovina; negotiations about a new agricultural agreement, an international arrangement for rationalizing our farm products; problems dealing with the environment that affect the supply of our cod stock off the Newfoundland coast; and the deposit of Soviet nuclear waste in the Arctic Ocean which will immediately spread into our own arena.
I mention only a very small sample of issues to prove an obvious point, which is that no such thing as domestic politics is left in Canada. In effect, we are all internationalized. Our jobs, our security, our well-being, and our welfare are all very dependent on and very conditioned by what happens in the world around us. We do not live in a fire-proof house.
What is essential for responding to this incredible turbulence and jungle of developments is that Canadians be informed, understand, and have knowledge so that they can make proper judgments about where this country will go and the kinds of stands we should take in responding to this multitude of global requirements and needs.
In a column that appeared in the Toronto Star this week by Carol Goar, in which the external affairs minister was defending her record as a minister against attacks that had been levelled in that column the week before, the minister said that people do not get enough information about Canada's activities around the world to make reasoned judgments. She went on to say that one of the primary requirements under her ministry would be to ensure a much broader based level of information and a more open discussion and debate about our options and choices.
It comes as some surprise that we arrive in the House of Commons on a Wednesday afternoon to find out that after the minister had made this proper assertion of the need for debate, information and understanding we now have a bill in front of us which will exterminate the most significant agency in the country providing that information, that debate and that understanding. It would be an understatement to call it a total contradiction.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was established in 1983 as an outgrowth of the then Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau's world peace initiative. However, it is important to recognize that it was
November 25, 1992

supported by all sides of the House. All parties in the House supported it because they understood that we needed the kind of institution that would have an independent base of operation to develop ideas, to disseminate information, and to participate in and create a marketplace of ideas.
Far be it from me to lecture members opposite about the marketplace. They are the experts on it. However, surely if they believe in the free marketplace of the economy they should believe in the free marketplace of ideas which means that a product must be generated to create a free exchange.
Yet what are they doing? They are exterminating, cancelling, and shutting down the source of these ideas in the crucial area of our international arena. I refrain from using the word "international" because that creates barriers in peoples' minds so that they say that the real gutsy things to talk about are what is happening here on the domestic level. However, as I tried to say earlier, there is no distinction between what is happening in the world around us and what happens here. Just ask the fishermen in Newfoundland, the grain farmers of western Canada, or the steel workers in Hamilton about how what has happened internationally has affected their own livelihood.
We are told this is a cost-saving measure. In fact, it is not a cost-saving measure because most of the budget of CIIPS has been transferred to the Department of External Affairs. That is what we were told.
The minister made announcements this summer that the Department of External Affairs would set up scholarship programs, and a new program of co-operative competitions to start research.
There is a difference, a very significant difference. The decision as to what those areas of research and debate will be are now going to be controlled by the Department of External Affairs. It will make the decisions on what is done. There will not be a free marketplace of ideas, and scholars will not be encouraged to search out new thinking but more to act as a rubber stamp for government policy.
Government Orders
We do not get innovation by simply trying to respond to the status quo. We do not get debate and new ideas by simply echoing official lines set out by the department.
Perhaps more tragic is the total cancellation of some of the most experimental and innovative work that CIIPS is doing. Let us return to the comment by the Secretary of State for External Affairs: "People do not get enough information about Canada's activities around the world to make reasoned judgments".
What was CIIPS doing? First it had a school program that supplied materials, speakers, lecture notes, videotapes, and other forms of information to the schools of Canada, to the young people of Canada, those who will have to live most directly with the impact of international events.
That has disappeared, I guess on the assumption that it does not help our young people to understand the world around us. Therefore the primary source of material to educate young people in our schools about world development has been shut down, cancelled.
More interesting is that CIIPS had just begun a joint project with the CBC and Radio Canada to develop televised programs on our national television networks discussing a series of problems on peacekeeping, environmental problems, global warming, security issues, and economic rearrangement. That would allow a two-way dialogue which Canadians could watch on their TV screens. It would provide an exposition of these problems. There would be a system through which various schools and universities could act as a means of providing a forum in which feedback could be received by members of Parliament and government.
An interesting exercise in public education on a massive scale using new technology is wiped out, disappeared, and gone. How can the Secretary of State for External Affairs, with any shred of integrity, any scintilla of honesty, state in a column in the Toronto Star that we need more information, more reasoned judgment, more debate and more dialogue when she is one of the authors of this bill eliminating the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, which had a mandate to provide the very same thing?

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
I do not use the word lightly, but hypocrisy immediately comes to my lips when I think of what the minister said in this statement and what the government is doing by eliminating this program.
The minister cannot with any degree of honesty make these kinds of statements about the need for informed and reasoned public information and dialogue and at the same time be a member of a government that is cancelling, eliminating, and exterminating the primary agency that supplied it.
Even if external affairs itself said: "Well, trust us. We have no politicized agenda", the fact of the matter is that the department has already received a number of budget hits from the finance minister, the latest one last week of 2 per cent. What will be left of its so-called research information program?
If we are to believe the Secretary of State for External Affairs, if her own members are to believe her, then we and they have no option but to vote for these amendments and stop the cancellation of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.

Madam Speaker, following the sterling remarks of my colleague from Winnipeg South Centre on the dissolution of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security I would like to make three short points.
The first concerns my perception that the government has acted prematurely to dissolve, liquidate and kill the agency before it had the authority to do so from Parliament. Someone on my staff today tried to reach CUPS and eventually got through to someone. They were told that apparently all the employees, with the exception of five board members, were laid off and given severance packages between June and July of this year. The person on the phone indicated that the only reason the phone lines were still open was because of a legal opinion that the operation must continue until the legislation had been approved by Parliament.
What is the government doing? It seems the right hand does not know what the left hand is doing. If the minister was here I would want to ask the minister-I am sorry, we are not supposed to comment on the presence or absence of the minister who does not have to be here now. However, in the event the opportunity arises to ask
the question I would want to ask what the heck the government is doing dissolving, liquidating, firing and severing when the agency has apparently received a legal opinion that the government should not be doing this until it had authority from Parliament? The government does not have authority from Parliament. That is why we are here today.
I just wanted to make that point as clearly as I could.
My next point concerns Motion No. 7, which is being grouped for debate in this grouping. That motion deals with the protection of the assets of the agency upon the dissolution or winding up of the agency to ensure that the assets are protected, kept intact and moved to another agency or another non-government agency, or at least some body, that could make use of the accumulated expertise of the agency that is being dissolved.
I note that in this particular case the library collection of this agency, which was extensive and valuable and noted at committee as being unique in Canada, I believe, has been transferred to the Canadian Forces Command and Staff College in Toronto.
I acknowledge that. It is exactly the kind of thing that the amendment had in mind.
Second, some of the program has been transferred to a new program which apparently has an annual budget of $2.1 million. This flies in the face of the purported cost-saving motive of the government in dissolving this agency.
Even though it transferred the assets and kept intact this valuable library which all Canadians own, I want to point out that there was never anything in the statute that required it to do that. I think that that kind of a direction should be in the statute when the agency is dissolved. That is why the amendment is there. The government has done it in any event, in relation to the library. We do not know what other assets may have been lost in the move, shall I say. I hope nothing has been lost, squandered or destroyed in the move.
The amendment is there. It should have been there on day one and I think it should be there for every agency dissolution. I wanted to make that point as well.

Madam Speaker, I would like to pick up on the comments that my colleague from Winnipeg South Centre made.
First, I consider it totally incomprehensible that the government would dissolve an institute like the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. Even though there are many Canadians in this country who are suffering and even though we are in deep economic pain, there would not be too many Canadians who would really support the dissolution of this if they really knew the full extent of the service that this organization provided.
My colleague talked about the school programs on world development that the institute has been providing and was continuing to expand. I can recall periods of time when this particular institute would supply speakers for town hall meetings. Sometimes there would be organizations or conferences that would not want a speaker who was advocating any particular partisan point of view. That was one of the unique things about this organization. It was perceived as an independent thinking operation. It was an independent service. With all the concerns and lack of trust in terms of partisan politics today, it seems that to destroy an organization that has such a fine reputation is not good logic.
I want to pick up on this issue of the library. Madam Speaker, I appeal through you to the government that this library that the institute has built up over a number of years is a very valued asset. Even though I am from Toronto and we all fight for our constituents and our communities, I think it is a mistake that that library goes to the Military Staff College in Toronto. That library should be here, somehow connected to our own library. I would be deathly afraid if one day I saw that library on the Crown assets list of DSS.
There is no guarantee that it could not happen. Obviously the government will use its force to ram through this legislation. I wish there would be some kind of a directive given that the Department of National Defence might find themselves running short of space one day and not realize the full extent and the value of this treasure that has been built up over many, many years.
Government Orders
I regret that in the excuse of debt reduction that we are cancelling this agency. It is a sad day. We obviously are appealing here in the last hours for the government to reconsider and all we can do is hope.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to respond to some comments made by hon. members opposite.
First of all, it should be understood that in his February budget, the Minister of Finance announced that certain councils and committees would be dissolved. He said this would be done in June. Administratively speaking, starting in June, the operations of these committees, councils and agencies were reduced to a minimum.
The official termination, however, will not take effect until the bill before the House today is passed. In other words, the process reflects due respect for the Parliament of Canada but also an understanding of the financial problems of the government and the responsibility this government has to Canadians.
Perhaps I may say a few words about the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, which was established in 1984 to increase knowledge and understanding from the perspective of arms control, disarmament, and other aspects of international peace and security. The institute also has a research role.
When preparing for the February budget, the Minister of Finance and the government realized it was more economical to ask the Department of External Affairs to do the work currently being done by the CUPS. When I say more economical, I am talking about a savings of $2.5 million annually. It will cost the government $2.5 million less annually, because instead of having the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, we will have officials within the Department of External Affairs doing the same job.
The February budget did not raise taxes. It did, however, announce cutbacks. What we are talking about this afternoon are those cutbacks. They are an important

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
part of our fight against the deficit and our constant struggle to stop Canada from getting deeper into debt. The opposition will probably say that $2.5 million annually is peanuts for the federal government. That may be. However, if every time a $2.5 million cut is feasible, and we do not cut, by the end of the day it all adds up.
All the files and assets of the institute have been transferred to the Department of External Affairs. For instance, the institute has transferred its library to the staff training college in Toronto, with the appropriate funding, so that external affairs officials can take over this responsibility.
It is important to realize that the work done by the institute will be carried on, but at lower cost, within the department. That is the message we must get across to our colleagues opposite.
Again, I think this bill should be passed as soon as possible to put the legal seal of approval on these administrative changes. Since by the end of June, these committees and institutes had practically wound up thenactivities.
Madam Speaker, I will defer to my hon. colleague for Windsor-St. Clair with your kind indulgence.

Madam Speaker, I had not really expected that I would be involved in this part of the debate. However, if the hon. parliamentary secretary represents the view of government, then we have stupidity compounded by innumeracy. He has tried to convince this House by standing up on this debate-which he recognizes is on television-that the expenditure of $2.5 million and the cancellation of that expenditure represents a part of the government's attempt to economize on this expenditure to a significant degree. He maintains that this fight against the deficit makes necessary the elimination of the Institute for International Peace and Security.
He says at the same time that the bureaucrats in External Affairs are going to do the job.
I say innumeracy because even the parliamentary secretary and this government ought to know that this government spills more money in taking polls than the cost of this. It spilled more money than this in its
prosperity initiative charade. It spent far more than this in sending propaganda to Windsor alone on NAFTA. He has the audacity, the nerve, if not the stupidity, to believe that the country and the electorate believe that we are to take him seriously when he says that we have to save $2.5 million on an institution that is studying peace and security in a world that is constantly threatened by insecurity and division and the prospect of war that has been accounted for by those who have preceded me in this debate.
It is absolutely outrageous that we have to be subjected to this kind of argument, that could do nothing but reflect upon the government in the worst way possible. That is the way in which it ought to be reflected because it is perhaps the worst government that this country has ever seen. To listen to this particular example of a misleading and stupid argument is something that the population should not be subjected to for very much longer. I just wanted to put that intervention on record.
To suggest that external affairs is a place where we are going to get independent judgment, where people are going to obtain information, is to belie the very character of the bureaucracy. The studies occurring at external affairs have one purpose and one purpose only. They are to reflect the policies of a government that, in the absence of this kind of institution, is not going to be subject to the kind of critical judgment, examination and research that ought to be available to it and to the people of Canada. What this government does in external affairs can be critically analysed and rejected or accepted depending upon its inherent merits and not the propaganda that is now going to be substituted for the institute that we are now abandoning.
If I sound angry, I hope it communicates to you, Madam Speaker, and to the government that I am not the only angry one about the garbage we hear in this House meant to justify the garbage that the government does.

Madam Speaker, I would like to commend to the House, at the risk of appearing boring by comparison, a question of perspective, because that really is what is before the House. As the hon. parliamentary secretary said, it is the intention of the government that the tasks previously discharged by the Canadian Institute for International Peace and
November 25, 1992

Security will now be undertaken and discharged by the bureaucrats of the Department of External Affairs.
I have nothing against the bureaucrats of the Department of External Affairs. I am certain that they are wonderfully competent, dedicated, well-trained, intelligent and well-motivated people. They are the products and exponents of a system of diplomacy and international relations that has just about come to the end of its tether.
The days in which we could find our security and the world's peace in a system of counterbalancing alliances netting the globe have passed. They have passed for a number of reasons but they have most certainly passed.
We are entered in an extremely perilous time on this planet, a time in which the extremes of wealth and poverty have never been greater and a time in which those who are caught in the extremes of poverty have never had greater access to the representation of wealth in which people like us live.
This is a recipe for the most violent and protracted forms of planetary social confrontation. It is these extremes more than any other factor, augmented it is true by climatic catastrophes and gradual changes but rooted in the maldistribution of wealth on our planet, which constitute the greatest threat to our security and the planet's peace, to the degree the planet can be said to know peace at any time this century.
What is required to meet these new challenges, especially for a comparatively wealthy middle power like Canada, is a complete rethinking of the precepts on which we base our international relations. With all due respect and compliments to the bureaucrats of the Department of External Affairs, they are singularly ill placed, not ill equipped, to undertake that absolutely vital ongoing reconsideration.
That being the case, it is simple good sense for the Canadian government on behalf of the Canadian people to create institutions which can foster, promote and disseminate that reconsideration.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was one such body, a very important body, in fact in these regards probably the pre-eminent body in
Government Orders
the country. That was recognized at its establishment in 1983 when it was given, as I understand at the time, unanimous support of this Chamber. That was a prescient move on the part of this Parliament at that time in the early 1980s. It is unfortunately an extremely blind move that is being contemplated by this Parliament now as it contemplates the eradication of the institute.
I would only ask members present and those who may be brought in for the vote to consider very carefully the needs that we have in a changed world, the requirement placed upon us as a comparatively wealthy society to use in part our wealth to find the means to foster peace and security around the planet. If we do not find those means they will not be found and the consequences will be dire indeed.

He said: Madam Speaker, this set of amendments tries to overturn the government's intention to eliminate the Economic Council of Canada.
The Economic Council of Canada had a proposed budget of about $10.3 million for this year. It had 118 full-time people working for it. It also had a council of 28 members, three of them full time and 25 part time.
It is striking that the House of Commons in this session before Christmas was said by the Prime Minister to be focusing especially on the economy of this country. We dealt with the divisive, difficult question of constitutional reform. It was rejected by the people, and the Prime Minister said that we would concentrate on the economy.
What is the very first legislation that in fact deals with the economy? It is of legislation which does away with
the independent body designed to provide advice to governments and to the people on what we should do about the economy.
One would think that any sensible government, any sensible Prime Minister, any Prime Minister who had thought things through at least a little, would have recognized that to get such independent advice not just from the professional researchers at the Economic Council but from business people, labour representatives and representatives of different social groups making up the council membership itself would have been absolutely paramount in the concerns of that Prime Minister.
What do we find instead? We find that the government is doing away with the Economic Council. Why? It is not to save money as the government will claim. There will be a speech made that it is to save money. In point of fact, as I can demonstrate and may do if I have enough time, there will not be any savings of money whatsoever in this fiscal year and very little in future fiscal years from doing away with the Economic Council of Canada, because every task the Economic Council is putting into effect and has been putting into effect will continue.
There has been a whole transfer of the projects of the Economic Council to a new institute at Queen's University for which, guess what, the Government of Canada is paying. It is not to save money. It is because the government could not face the fact of receiving independent criticism from the Economic Council. It could not face the fact that an independent group of business people, of economists and of labour people would actually say that the government was wrong, as this council has said consistently as this government has put us further and further into an economic mess in the past three years.
That is why this council is being eliminated. It is a question of shooting the messenger because the government did not like the message. That is what is at issue here.
The reality is that the institution has done and is doing excellent work. It has done work on health care, how to develop a more efficient, economically effective method of dealing with our health care problems, one of the crucial issues faced by every provincial government and

November 25, 1992

this federal government. Yet the government is doing away with the institution.
It is an institution which is tracking Canadian poverty. Perhaps that is something that made the government angiy at the institution. The Economic Council showed in its studies that poverty was increasing under the government. Maybe that was the mistake. Maybe it was the mistake that this council committed when it said that the high interest rate policies of the government and the high value of the Canadian dollar were causing the tremendous increase in unemployment. Maybe that was the reason.
It could not have been because the Economic Council was wrong about free trade. Mark my words, the Economic Council was wrong about free trade. It predicted that in the first five years of free trade there would be hundreds of thousands of new jobs. We have seen in the first four years of free trade a loss of something close to
500,000	jobs in this country.
The government refuses to admit that. The government refuses to criticize free trade. The government refuses to change its mind about free trade. It cannot be that the Economic Council was wrong about that subject which disturbs the government. In fact the government used to quote the Economic Council day after day in the last election campaign because it liked the message then. It liked the message because it seemed to be something that was supportive of what the government was trying to promote.
I want to leave the people of this country as they watch this debate with two quotations and a final set of realities. The first quotation is from the president of the now defunct Economic Council when he spoke to our committee. The president said, summing up what would happen with the elimination of this council: "We are losing our capacity to build our knowledge of Canadian society by testing theories against Canadian data".
I also want to quote from an independent research institute which makes its money not from government but independently. The president of Informetrica said: "The council is indispensable for its ability to assign teams of economists to big projects. University researchers and private sector firms cannot mount the long-term,
Government Orders
large-scale projects the council undertook". That is what we are losing.
However, I have to admit that I thought in the past when we first heard the debate around eliminating the Economic Council that maybe the government actually did believe it was going to save some money, no matter how little, and it justified eliminating this independent voice which would help us reform, change and improve our economic policy. I thought the government might actually have been telling the truth.
What emerged from the government was the prosperity report inventing our future. It was called "An Action Plan for Canada's Prosperity". The action consisted of recommending the establishment, believe it or not, of not just an economic council, but six new economic and social institutions which would fill exactly the same roles as the Economic Council.
I conclude by listing these because what is being suggested is staggering. We will get rid of the Economic Council and replace it with a national quality institute, a centre for excellence for sustainable development, a Canadian forum on learning, a federal-provincial body which is supposed to examine economic prospects and propose fiscal stances, another federal-provincial body, and finally a prosperity council. How is this prosperity council to be formed? In exactly the same way as the Economic Council of Canada was formed.
This government is trying to hoodwink Canadians. It is trying to get rid of the Economic Council. It is trying to replace it with far more expensive institutions which will simply parrot the government's line as opposed to the independent advice which the Economic Council has provided this country so valuably in the past.

Madam Speaker, may I say first of all that for once I agree almost entirely with what my colleague from Essex-Windsor has said in his comments on the Economic Council of Canada.
The hon. member and I served together for a long time on the finance committee and received many submissions from the Economic Council of Canada. There were many appearances by the chairman of the council as well as members of the council before us to discuss a variety of issues.

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
It causes me some sadness to be participating in a debate about the demise of the Economic Council of Canada. I suppose the situation in which the government finds itself, having again failed to estimate properly its revenues for the current year, running a deficit which is going to be somewhere in the order of $35 billion after having estimated something less than $28 billion in their budget last year; in other words, having achieved a deficit that exceeds the prediction by something close to 30 per cent, is unsettling.
I understand why it may say it needs to save money, but as the member for Essex-Windsor has just pointed out, in fact the effort here is not one to save expense. If it were a matter of saving expense, many of the other initiatives introduced by the government in order to talk economic policy would not have been on the table. We would not have just spent a pile of money on something called a prosperity initiative study which has produced yet another volume of reports and information which is entirely redundant, together with what was already produced. That, as my friend reminds me, was on untendered contracts.
My purpose in speaking is really to say that the Economic Council of Canada is an institution for which Canadians should have a large degree of pride. I would like to point out the work that has been performed by the council before the announcement was made.
The council was preparing, at the time the budget was released, an important study on education in Canada. That report was issued shortly after the budget, a study called A Lot to Learn: Education and Training in Canada.
Canadians should be aware of this work because not only does it have a great deal to say to us about where we are and where we should be going, but it is an indication of the valuable work that a body such as the Economic Council of Canada can perform.
As we all know, education lies within provincial jurisdiction. We also know that we as Canadians cannot stand by impervious to what is happening outside our borders. We must begin to find ways to equip our people to deal with the competition that we face and the production of goods and services not only in the United
States and Mexico, but in Europe, in Japan and increasingly in the developing world.
Again and again we discover that it is in our ability to equip our most important resource, the human resource, that we need to focus attention. If we fail to prepare our people for the global competition in which our nation is engaged, we will fail to maintain the standard of living that our people have every right to hope for and to expect and we will fail to perform our role as a developed and resource rich country in aiding in the alleviation of poverty elsewhere in the world.
The council's study discovered, among other things, that 30 per cent of Canadian adults who have completed their secondary education have difficulty reading and try to avoid situations that require reading. Thirty-six per cent of adults in the same group cannot perform simple sequences of numerical operations that would enable them to meet most everyday demands. I am quoting from the report A Lot to Learn: Education and Training in Canada.
From the same report are results for science and mathematics, which can be summarized as follows: At age 10, Canadian children compare favourably with those in most industrialized countries. By age 13 or 14, Canada's relative position deteriorates somewhat, though evidence on this is somewhat mixed. By the end of secondary school, Canada's achievement is weak when adjusted per years of schooling, retention rates and freedom of subject choice. The result is particularly pronounced in science but it seems to hold for mathematics as well.
This information is of crucial importance to Canadians in determining how we face the challenges of the future. This is the work produced this year by the Economic Council of Canada. It is able to do this on a budget which is not overly generous because of a broad mandate to study issues related to the economic welfare of Canada.
An existing institution such as this can be redirected, retooled, re-equipped far more effectively, efficiently and with less waste of money than the government has engaged in by disbanding the existing organization and trying to redirect the finances into other efforts that are primarily intended for show rather than for the product they will produce.
November 25, 1992

I would like to cite another 1992 report. It is again by the Economic Council of Canada: The New Face of Poverty: Income Security Needs of Canadian Families.

I am sure people hearing of the disbanding of the Economic Council of Canada have given it very little thought other than to think, well good, perhaps government is cutting back, saving a few dollars here and there.
It is crucial that government have this information. However, it is unusual that an independent agency funded by the Government of Canada can say this, the opening words of the foreword. "The war against poverty stalled in the 1980s".
How important is it that an agency be able to make that statement in the face of the rhetoric that we hear on a regular basis from the other side of the House of Commons? We have been told since this government was elected that poverty has declined when in fact, according to the council, the war on poverty stalled in 1980s.
This is the kind of critical analysis that it is crucial for us to have in order to be able to make the proper policy judgments that are needed as we move through this decade.
The projects, the papers, the work that was ongoing are enormous. This is a council that was extremely productive. Publications alone from 1989 to 1991 include three annual reviews; four council statements on reports, one on Globalization and Canada's Financial Markets in 1989; Good Jobs, Bad Jobs: Employment in the Service Sector in 1990; From the Bottom Up: The Community Economic Development Approach in 1990; New Faces in the Crowd: Economic and Social Impacts of Immigration in 1991.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak this afternoon to the report stage of the legislation before us which deals with cutting back certain agencies which have been appointed in the course of deliberations in the House of Commons.
We are talking about eliminating the Economic Council which was mandated in 1963 to provide advice and ways to increase economic growth and improve the quality of life for Canadians.
With a multisector body of 28 members, a staff of 118 and an annual budget of $10.3 million, the council has produced over the years numerous studies and reports, including an annual review of medium and long-term economic prospects and problems.
The budget announcement to wind up the council was made in light of the government's need to carefully assess the priorities for the limited funding available for arm's length research and advice.
As I said before, the council had been established in 1963 at a time when the infrastructure for research was far less developed than it is now. Today, there are many other sources of such advice in places such as universities and think tanks like the Conference Board, the C.D. Howe Institute, the Fraser Institute and the Institute of Research and Public Policy to name but a few.
The government can no longer afford to support a separate organization for these purposes.

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
Of the studies under way at the council at the time of announcing the closure, the government decided that five studies should be completed. These studies deal with the government and competitiveness-this was initiated by the council at the Prime Minister's request I might add-human resources management in Canada, cost effectiveness of the Canadian health care system, Canada's changing industrial structure and adaption strategies and Canada's commercial relations with the Pacific rim.
Three of the studies are now being completed through a contract with the University of Ottawa and Queen's University and are being overseen by the Department of Industry, Trade and Commerce. CIDA and Statistics Canada are handling the other two studies.
Funding has been provided by Treasury Board for these contracts. The savings estimated at budget time for the closure of the agency are coming to fruition. The government will save $10.3 million annually, minus the cost of finishing the existing studies that I have just outlined.
In conclusion, the closure of the Economic Council will result in the government achieving its goal of saving taxpayers' money, rationalizing government and better targeting of funding for economic research and advice.
As with all other agencies to be wound up, the government requested the council and the Department of Industry, Science and Technology to prepare a windup plan. The aim was to ensure that the assets of this organization were protected, that the employees were treated in a fair and a humane manner, and that arrangements were made for existing contractual commitments.
In a letter dated June 10 of this year the chairman of the Economic Council wrote to the legislative committee on Bill C-63 confirming arrangements that were made regarding its assets. The letter indicated the library collections were turned over to the National Library pursuant to the National Library Act. The electronic data holding including the economic models were disposed of pursuant to the National Archives Act. The method of operating and manipulating the models was documented and the models were then transferred to the archives.
We have before us tonight the legislation reported back from the legislative committee without amendment, permitting the government to move forward with this piece of legislation which flows from this year's budget to completion. I trust we will be able to vote on it now.
