He said: Mr. Speaker, at this stage we are dealing with a third institution which the government has sought to eliminate. We on this side of the House feel it has been serving a useful purpose and has been, in this case, an important institution for Atlantic Canada in particular.
The International Centre for Ocean Development is the institution with which these particular amendments deal. Again the attempt is to eliminate the clauses of the bill which seeks to wind up various institutions, dealing with winding up the International Centre for Ocean Development or ICOD.
ICOD is an organization which was announced in 1981 at a Commonwealth Head of States Conference. It was incorporated following the 1982 signing of the UN Conference on the Law of the Sea. It therefore was something that very much followed on an objective for which the Canadian government had fought for many years: the establishment of a Law of the Sea treaty.
The centre became a Crown corporation in 1985. As of 1992-93 it was costing the people of Canada something in the order of $13.3 million. Of the 74 people who worked for it, most of them were in Halifax, some were overseas and some were in Ottawa. It also had a board of directors including a chairman, a president, seven directors from Canada, and up to five directors internationally-
This centre, as we discovered in our discussions in committee, was of importance for two reasons. First, it was of importance because it dealt with many of the serious concerns not just of Canada but of many countries in trying to manage the ocean's resources effectively. We in this country of all countries should be aware of the immense potential problems which exist in ocean management.
Government Orders
We have seen the Atlantic coast fisheries devastated by the failures in ocean management. We have seen the complete shutdown of large parts of the Newfoundland fishery. We have seen the near shutdown of large parts of the gulf fishery. This is just one example of the tremendous cost to the country of not managing ocean resources properly.
This institution was established to help Canada and to help poorer developing countries throughout the world carry forward such ocean management successfully.
Again the government will claim that it is saving money by shutting this institution down. Yet every bit of activity which ICOD is undertaking is being transferred to CIDA and to funding by CIDA. This means that in practice we will be spending virtually the same amount of money. We will probably find ourselves having to spend even more money in dealing with some of our domestic oceans management problems as a consequence of winding up ICOD.
The second point however which is important about this institution is that it is one of the few institutions located in Atlantic Canada. It is one of the few government bodies established there on an independent basis providing inputs, professional jobs and specialized activities for scientists in Atlantic Canada. It is some way in which this government offers to the people of Atlantic Canada a chance to participate in trying to develop policy and work with the Government of Canada on ocean management questions which are important to Atlantic Canada and important throughout the world.
We had testimony in front of the legislative committee indicating to us these very significant contributions to the Atlantic Canada economy, especially for professional employment, especially for the scientific employment which ICOD provided. Yet we have the government eliminating this institution despite the fact that much of the expenditure will continue to be made. The difference is that the expenditure will not be made in Atlantic Canada. It will be made in central Canada. There will be a shift in resources contributing to the well-being of Atlantic Canada from the Halifax area to Ottawa.
I cannot see how it makes any sense, in a country already marked by inequalities of opportunity and inequalities of government activity in Atlantic Canada compared with central Canada, to shut down this institu-

If there is one thing the crowd on the other side of the House cannot stand, it is having someone tell them they are doing something wrong. To put it differently, even when they are told they are doing something wrong they do not much care. Remember, 85 per cent of Canadian people told them they did not want the GST but they got it anyway.
Without seeking to defeat my own argument, what is the point if government gets advice on anything? It is not followed anyway. That is why the fishery in Atlantic Canada is in the mess it is. That is why the fishery on the west coast of Canada is in the mess it is. It is because the management of the ocean resources by this administration has been absolutely abysmal and shameful.
If that were just a bit of rhetoric, if that were just a few words, what difference? There may be a few people watching television or some people here, but what is the difference? Behind those words is the reality that thousands upon thousands of people in Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and P.E.I. are suffering tonight. Thousands of families are suffering tonight. Thousands of heads of households, men and women, are faced with great uncertainty tonight throughout Atlantic Canada. They can no longer do what they were traditionally able to do because of the bungled management of the ocean resources by this administration.
Then, government has the gall to come in here and ask me because I represent the people of Ramea and the

Government Orders
people of Burgeo, Grand-Bruit, Grey River and those other dozens of communities that are being devastated by the mismanagement of the cod stocks: "Would you agree to putting out of existence yet another agency dedicated to the marine environment and ocean resources?" My answer to that government on behalf of those people in those communities is: "No, I will not agree to that. No, I will not agree".

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, just a short recap on what these motions are about.
In the February 1992 budget, it was decided to wind up the International Centre for Ocean Development. ICOD was doing some of the same functions being done by CIDA, the Canadian International Development Agency. The role of ICOD does not require that it be a separate organization. This is why the government decided to wind up ICOD and transfer its resources to CIDA.
The resulting savings in overhead, some $3.3 million, will be redirected within the official development assistance envelope for programming. CIDA will take the appropriate measures to ensure that assistance in relation to ocean resources continues to be provided to developing countries.
The work of ICOD has been accomplished with a staff of 74 and an annual budget of $13.3 million. At the government's request, ICOD and CIDA have prepared a wind-up plan for approval. The plan which was approved by Treasury Board outlines a fair and humane severance package for ICOD employees and the transfer of necessary working files to CIDA and the arrangements for ICOD's existing contractual agreements. For example, ICOD has contracted its programming activities to the Consulting and Audit Group of Canada pending parliamentary approval of dissolution. After dissolution, CIDA will assume this contract.
In conclusion, the government's decision to wind up ICOD will mean more aid for international programming for developing countries. It will mean less overhead and a rationalization of the government's department and agency portfolio.

Mr. Speaker, I want to add a couple of points to the debate from the submission of the hon. member opposite.
The assets and the surviving program of the International Centre for Ocean Development are being transferred or rolled over to CIDA. One can only hope that CIDA will pursue the objectives, the mandate and the functions of the international centre with as much vigour as the international centre itself did.
There are not too many other things that I can usefully contribute to the debate, other than quote a statement made in 1985 by the Hon. Stewart Mclnnes who was then parliamentary secretary to the minister for international trade.
At that time, the international centre was in business. It was in the process of undertaking projects aimed at developing food resources in the sea in underdeveloped countries. I gather that has gone on in some 35 countries. It did a good job. It is still doing a good job even though it appears as though the centre is out of business now.
In 1985 Mr. Mclnnes said: "We believe that the International Centre for Ocean Development will add an important new dimension to our efforts to assist less fortunate nations. Canada, a great maritime centre, will use this centre to share its long experience and expertise in maritime resource management. As we are all aware, the ocean is a potential major source of food that needs to be developed as soon as possible".
I will close by noting that at a year in this century when Canada appears to have mismanaged its own cod stocks on the east coast, creating a desperate situation there, it is the same year that this government decides we should no longer be in the business of providing expertise through the international centre to the less developed countries. Maybe it is an appropriate year to dissolve.

Mr. Speaker, I thank all my colleagues in the House. I have been watching many of them debate these motions on television. I must be a little bit masochistic to sit there and watch them when there are so many other choices.
However, it is a good debate. It brings, through the member for Mississauga who is on the government benches and is always, even though I disagree with him most of the time, controversial and engages the debate. He is truly one of the best exponents of the Conservative philosophy. It is not my philosophy but he puts it forward very well.
The hon. member for Essex-Windsor, the NDP finance critic, has really made the point in the debate for our side. One of the points he made, and it is an important point and it certainly pertains to these amendments on the Law Reform Commission, is that the government is really not going to save money in the long run. It is just taking the money that it would spend on some of these problems and shifting it over to other bodies or other ways of doing it. It is the same amount of money, but the difference is that it will control the other bodies, it will control what is being said. In other words, these will not be independent bodies.
The member gave the example of the Economic Council of Canada. The council was a bit of a thorn in the side of the government; that is gone. Now we have studies by an institute at Queen's and other studies through the finance department, and so on, which will, of course, be controlled by the government because it pays the piper.
I want to talk about the Law Reform Commission. These amendments deal specifically with the Law Reform Commission. I am the justice critic for the federal NDP and as a lawyer I have been involved over many years. Actually I became a lawyer about the time the Law Reform Commission was established in 1971. The Law Reform Commission is 20 years old.
It was established by the Law Reform Commission Act and it reports to Parliament through the Minister of Justice. Its mandate was to provide an ongoing review of the statutes of Canada to make recommendations for improvement, modernization and reform of legislation. It undertook some research in-house, contracted out other work to consultants on a full or part-time basis, held seminars and conferences, visited universities and

Government Orders
schools, published articles and learned journals, et cetera.
If I can put it in plain English, the Law Reform Commission looked at changing the law in a systematic, very intelligent, rational way and it has produced good results. Recently we were forced by the courts to pass new legislation on mental health because the old law was against the charter of rights. On abortions, on juries, the courts in fact threw out parts of the law and we had to come back to Parliament and revise it so that it would be within the charter of rights. In some of those cases the Law Reform Commission had long recommended this reform before it happened.
We dealt with a bill called the Contraventions Act. It took a number of minor federal statutes like speeding a boat, minor pollution laws, trespassing on federal property in a national park, being in the park without a permit or licence and so on and put forward a very simple procedure to deal with them, much as we do with the highway traffic acts when one gets a speeding or parking ticket in the province or city in which one lives. The Law Reform Commission had recommended that awhile ago and we in Parliament followed what the Law Reform Commission had recommended.
The Law Reform Commission was working, it was independent and it was producing these reports that were useful. We were spending about $4.8 million a year. What is going to happen now? We are going to do the research in-house. We are going to do it by contracting out of the Department of Justice and so on.
Does the House know what that will mean? It will mean more bucks for some big, fat Vancouver law firms. They are already making a lot of money from this minister. It will be more contracts to their friends and reports that the government can live with. If it does not like the report, it will not make it public, whereas the Law Reform Commission reports were always public because it reported to Parliament.
One of the commission's highlights for 1992 to 1993 was to continue a comprehensive study of the Criminal Code. Several recommendations by the commission have been used by the Supreme Court, other courts, lawyers or incorporated in government and private members' bills. I am a member, along with my colleague from the
Liberal Party, the member for Cape Breton on the justice committee. Part of the subcommittee of that committee is considering revisions to the general part of the Criminal Code and we have used the work of the Law Reform Commission.
Here we had something that was working, something that was not too expensive, something useful and something that was independent of this government. That is the rub. It does not want an independent body. It wants to do the research in-house. It is going to spend the same amount of money and control the research.
I am concerned about some of the reactions to the demise of the Law Reform Commission. JJ. Camp, president of the Canadian Bar Association was quoted in The Ottawa Citizen, March 11, 1992, as saying: "I have had it reported to me by some sources that the Law Reform Commission was too independent. I bridle at that because I do not believe there is such a thing as being too independent". This did not come from the justice critic of the NDP, or the justice critic of the Liberal Party who is in the House tonight. This came from the president of the Canadian Bar Association.
Also, Vincent Del Buono, the president of the Society for the Reform of Criminal Law, is quoted in The Ottawa Citizen as saying: "The Law Reform Commission, both in terms of the legal talent it has nurtured in Canada and abroad and the prestige that its recommendations hold, has had a far greater impact than the simple mechanical assessment of its legislative implementation record would suggest. The fact of the matter is that this is a small change and what we are doing is taking the engines of new ideas and future thinking in the government and cutting them off". That is a serious charge that Mr. Del Buono makes.
In other words, here is a place where there are fresh and new ideas and we are cutting them off. Also, the president of-

-the Association des avocats de la defense de Montreal said in La Presse, and I quote: "The federal government used its latest budget to terminate the Law Reform Commission of Canada, an agency whose relevance to the Canadian legal system was recognized across this
November 25, 1992

country. We feel this so-called austerity measure is entirely unjustified".
[English)
He said that this decision, taken supposedly for economic matters or to save money, was unjustified. I did not say that. It was the President of the Montreal Defence Advocates Association. They are lawyers in Montreal and independent, outside sources.
A lawyer working for the Law Reform Commission who is not quite so independent, put it very well. She is Susan Zimmerman and one of the few people who did this. Some people in the Law Reform Commission managed to get some nice jobs out of the government. They sort of got paid off so that they would not make comments about the demise of the commission. This woman had some courage to do it.
She said: "The commission was created to provide a vehicle for lawyers and occasionally philosophers to reflect on the law as it stands and as it ought to be. This is not an idle pursuit. It is a vital part of the life of a healthy democracy which is founded on the rule of law".
The Minister of Justice made a famous speech. Perhaps it is not as famous as her Madonna-like posing in the recent coffee table photograph book. In her more serious endeavour, she said earlier this year that politicians were too often letting the courts make tough decisions for them. She called this "an abdication of Parliament's role as the primary agent of social change".
The Minister of Justice says that Parliament should be making the social change and changing the law. In fact, what we should have been doing in this Parliament, in the time of this Minister of Justice who is spoken of now as the next Conservative leader, is looking at the record. The record is that we have been responding to the courts that have told us we have to change the Mental Health Act and the abortion and juries part of the Criminal Code and so on. It refers to a number of acts along with the abortion part of the Criminal Code.
We have not been carrying this out the way we are supposed to. The Minister of Justice was right originally. We have to be the agents of legal change in this Parliament. We need independent advice to do that. We
Government Orders
had it from the Law Reform Commission of Canada. It cost us $4 million, but we are going to spend the money anyway. We are going to spend it in contracts.
Instead of sending it to fat law firms and to consultants who are in the pocket of the Department of Justice, I say that it would be better to keep the Law Reform Commission of Canada. There are only two other countries in the industrialized world that do not have a Law Reform Commission. This is a false economy and I challenge my friends to get up and defend this saving because I say that this is indefensible. If you want to save money, there are lots of ways you could save money. This is a small amount and it is an important amount. It created an independent commission which we do not have any more.

Mr. Speaker, I would first of all like to follow up on the last remark of my colleague from Port Moody-Coquitlam when he talked about the money for the Law Reform Commission as being a small amount, but an important amount.
What we mean is that relatively speaking it is a small amount, $4.8 million, considering the good that this funding has done. This funding has acted as a cement to our legal system in Canada, along with our Supreme Court of Canada.
The member from Mississauga, who would have no more idea about the rule of law than he would about a turkey shoot, would not know the difference. His philosophy is that if you do not like somebody take them out and tie them to a parking meter, if there are not any stocks available in your community.
The Law Reform Commission goes back centuries in Great Britain. It goes back in this country to 1968 when the Canadian Bar Association actually requested that the governments of this country enter into these organizations so that we would have a means of projecting the needs of our legal system into the future. In this way our law would always have something to look to in terms of important writing and original thinking, and we would be able to take not a whole book, not a whole concept, but various ideas from one writing, from one periodical, and bring together new laws that reflect the needs of society

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
at a particular time. This was done when the Law Reform Commission was set up in 1971.
It has existed and done excellent work since that date. In fact, all of the provinces in Canada have Law Reform Commissions. The only government jurisdiction of the 11 federal and provincial governments that does not have one now is the federal government. All the provinces have Law Reform Commissions but the federal government does not. In a federal system of government that is absolutely incredible, absolutely stupid. Not only that, but in the British Commonwealth of Nations, Canada now joins Bangladesh and Zimbabwe as the only three countries in the Commonwealth without a Law Reform Commission.
There are those who say that the Law Reform Commission has not done anything because it has never had its ideas put into law holus-bolus. Well, that is not the way it works. Not any piece of writing, not any organization, not any person has all the right concepts needed to formulate the law for the future, but the concepts have to be there. Some will be chosen, some will not. The idea is that there be some thinking ahead into the future.
The importance of the Law Reform Commission is reflected in the fact that work of the Law Reform Commission has been cited in 255 court decisions in this country, including 44 decisions of the Supreme Court of Canada.
As my friend from Port Moody-Coquitlam has said, what the government hopes to do in closing down the Law Reform Commission is do this work itself, which is an entirely different idea than allowing the Law Reform Commission to do it.
As the member mentioned, J. J. Camp, the former president of the Canadian Bar Association, said: "I have heard it said that they were too independent",-meaning the Law Reform Commission-"I do not think that is possible".
If the government takes it over and does it in-house it will, as my learned friend from Port Moody-Coquitlam has said, probably wind up spending as much if not more. The difference will be that it will not be original thinking. The government will be able to bring forward the ideas it wants brought forward. It will be engendering its own thinking as it wants to impose it. What a terrible
situation in a free countiy like Canada. What an odious procedure.
The Department of Justice is too prosecutorial. It looks at one side. The government departments, and the Department of Justice in particular, will have a conflict of interest because they will be bringing forward ideas in which they are engaged or plan to be engaged. That is like allowing the lawyer for the plaintiff or the defendant in a case before the courts write the decision. It is absolutely incredible and totally unacceptable.
As well, a policy paper may be used by the opposing side against the government. If the government introduces an idea, a concept, then that is forward, front and centre, as the thinking of the Department of Justice.
In a subsequent case, what is to stop a lawyer from taking this position of the Department of Justice and putting it before the court, from saying: "My lord, the Department of Justice is advocating this position, which I am now advocating in this case against the Department of Justice".
What a stupid position for the Department of Justice to put itself in. What an absolutely ludicrous procedure. Not only that, but we may never even find out what the writings are and what they state. We may never actually see the reports. The government may decide it wants to use the reports itself and therefore will not release them for others to benefit from them. No more will we have the courts relying on and quoting the work of the Law Reform Commission.
This whole procedure is totally offensive. Not only has the Law Reform Commission been quoted but in the 20 years since its creation it has produced 33 reports to Parliament, 61 working papers and 76 study papers.
A lot of that work will never be used. Some may say that it is frivolous, useless work. People could say that certainly about this House, and particularly about this government, yet its salaries and budgets go on.
I would say categorically that the work of the Law Reform Commission has provided much more benefit, generally speaking, than the work of this government, which has decimated the economy of this country.
November 25, 1992

It has been done because this government does not like criticism. This government does not want independent thinking. This government is totally and utterly afraid of new ideas. This government is an unmitigated Neanderthal. The reason for this is not cost cutting. The reason is the government does not want criticism.
I just want to read a couple of quotes. In Washington, the Solicitor General, the former Minister of Justice, stated that we in Canada are proud of the work of the Law Reform Commission. That was the former Minister of Justice. The present Minister of Justice stated in May 1990 that the commission's draft Criminal Code, which has been the subject of so much favourable comment both in Canada and internationally, would be of great assistance to the committee in its review, which is presently going on, of the general provisions of the Criminal Code.
The present Minister of Justice praised the work of the Law Reform Commission on the Criminal Code. No one except this government applauds the demise of the Law Reform Commission. We on this side of the House and members of the legal profession would say that this is a dark moment for law and legal thinking in Canada. We can only hope, although we have no precedent for this, that the government will show some intelligence and change its mind on this matter.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to say a few words in this debate.
I will agree with the hon. members who have spoken when they said that the Law Reform Commission has done good work. Yes, it has done good work. It was created in 1971 to help governments overhaul their laws and certainly it has done good work. Various governments have listened to its advice on many occasions and we have overhauled laws.
It costs $4.9 million each year. It has five full-time commissioners and a staff of 36. That is a lot of staff and a lot of commissioners, and it costs a lot of money.
It is my belief that in Canada we have created too many commissions and too many boards, and in a certain way we have devalued Parliament. I would rather see work of this nature done by parliamentary committees.
Government Orders
The member for Windsor-St. Clair has spoken so eloquently in committee meetings about the value of Parliament and how Canadians want to change. Part of that change should be that we should do more work like that done by the Law Reform Commission in the past.
It is too easy to spin out regulatory agencies and advisory bodies and so on. However, what is the role of Parliament and the role of committees but to give advice to the government? History since the McGrath commission in 1986 has shown that committees have given very independent and very good advice.
The laws that have emanated from Parliament after the reforms have been better laws than they would have been before House of Commons reform.
I ask my opposition colleagues where Parliament should fit in. Do we always have to spin off things that Parliament should be doing? Do they not believe in parliamentary reform? They talk a good story. Yet they want to create commissions and spend money and only do the politicking, but not the serious business of looking at policy in an analytical way, creating public policy and coming up with new ideas, which is what we should be doing.
Parliament has a role to play. The justice committee, of which I am a member as is the previous member who spoke and the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, is involved, and has been, in several major studies. We have had an impact. Perhaps what should be done is to generally beef up the research bureaus of parliamentary committees and empower them to come forward with policy positions and papers.
Some committees have appended draft laws to then-reports and have suggested the House leaders consider these draft laws and the government adopt and introduce them. Private members have come forward with their own private members' bills to improve the laws in the country.
I say to my colleagues in response, we have had an independent agency that has done a lot of good work but it is time we ourselves did this work and brought some prestige back to Parliament. Let us not devalue Parliament by giving its role to outsiders. We can do that independent work.

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
There is also a fiscal argument here. It is an expenditure of $5 million a year. We have had a deficit over the past years of roughly $30 billion a year, now $34.6 billion has to be borrowed. We have to borrow that money each year and then we have to borrow money to cover the interest on that money each year. It is a vicious cycle.
The government has had to take a hard look at where we spend our money. Some of this work will be contracted out but there will be a net saving. There will be a net saving this year of $300,000, and $2.1 million annually in the future.
Some work will be contracted from the Department of Justice but it is my hope that the justice committee itself will be able to do some of this work. The people involved in the Law Reform Commission have been placed elsewhere. I understand that most of them have jobs.
The government has been quite responsible in looking after the people who were affected by this. The library and research material has been transferred to the Department of Justice. I am sure, as the justice committee or as individual members of Parliament, if we asked to see some of that research, we would have access to that material too.
I support this bill to streamline a number of agencies, of which one is the Law Reform Commission. The Law Reform Commission has done good work but it is time for Parliament to regain its role as the maker of policy. It is time for committees to come forward with new ideas and reforms. I believe we can do that. It is time to get our fiscal house in order and this is one small part of it. Five million dollars a year is not insignificant. Opposition members think that money grows on trees. Everyone pays taxes and that is a lot of tax dollars, $5 million.
I believe we are doing the right thing.

Mr. Speaker, I have one short comment on the issue of independence of these advisory bodies. At the moment we are speaking about the Law Reform Commission of Canada.
Have we ever thought about how absolutely difficult it is, maybe even impossible, for career civil servants in one of the ministries-let us take the Department of Justice-to do some original research. They make an original,
independent proposal to the minister. I say that this just does not happen any more, that individuals in the Public Service have a career and their job is basically to do their job, to do what the minister wants them to do.
When the minister and the government say they want to embark on a certain path, the department will simply do that. I do not want to call all civil servants yes men and yes women, but basically they are going to do the job they are asked to do. They are going to do it in the way that is most consistent in the eyes of the minister, so that the minister will smile and indicate that they are a great workers and have done a great job and they will go a long way in the department.
The problem is that there does not exist enough mechanisms, if any, within the Public Service to generate the independent approach that is absolutely critical in giving government some guidance for the future. That is the kind of advice and research that the Law Reform Commission has been carrying on for a couple of decades.
Members opposite may even acknowledge, some of them will not, the leading role in independent advice that this agency has given. Other agencies-and we are dealing with she here today-have done that same kind of independent research and to government and given advice to Parliament. We are now going to be without it.
It is naive to believe that the justice department is going to commission some original work or research or drafting that is going to give it a product that varies one iota from the product that the justice ministry wants or that they wanted when they started out.
We need a mechanism like the Law Reform Commission. I regret that we are losing it.

Mr. Speaker, I do not have a long speech to give. The House will appreciate that I like to keep my comments concise. I was encouraged to get to my feet after the remarks by the member for Edmonton-Strathcona suggesting that the justice committee of the House is now going to take over the work of the Law Reform Commission. That is pure, unadulterated smoke and mirrors.
I came to this place from the criminal justice system and I know of the work that has been done over the last more than 20 years by the Law Reform Commission. We
November 25, 1992

need an independent body that can take the time to do some future thinking, to look at the Criminal Code, to look at how laws are evolving, to look at how juries are dealing with certain matters, to look at how different judges in different areas of the country are dealing with things, to look at what is being said by the public, to hear what the public interest is saying.
We need an independent body that can do that kind of futuristic analysis and reporting to the Minister of Justice and to Parliament.
When we hear a member of the justice committee on the government side suggesting spuriously to this House that the justice committee is going to pick this up and carry it, he is doing a disservice to this House and a disservice to all Canadians who are interested in this. He might think the justice committee is actually going to do it but it cannot. It is functionally impossible, no matter how much you reform it.
Let us look at the last couple of months. The House was sitting in June. It was closed in July and August. There was the referendum in September and October. There is a four month period, one-third of the year, gone where the justice committee never sat one day, one hour, one minute on a single issue. During that whole period of time an independent body like the Law Reform Commission can carry on its ongoing investigations and research into changes that this Parliament needs to enact over time.
Earlier today we heard one of the members on the government side saying it costs $200,000 a day for the House of Commons to sit or maybe he even said $200,000 an hour, some preposterous sum at any rate. The total budget in the most recent 1991-92 fiscal year for the Law Reform Commission was $4.9 million for 36 person-years.
If the government side were really serious, that its serious intention was to put an adjunct body attached to the justice committee, do you not think the justice committee would have seen some kind of a work plan, that Whips and House Leaders would have had some discussions about a multimillion dollar adjunct body being attached to Parliament? It might have been a good idea if the government had been serious about it.
I still do not think it would have been as good as an independent commission. I do not think smoke and
Government Orders
mirrors and charade-like arguments should be put on the floor of the House. I do not think anyone who has been associated with the Law Reform Commission for a moment thinks that anything other than the one comment that the member did make is likely to be true and it is that this kind of work is to be contracted out to law firms that are friends with the government or firms that are likely to deliver the kind of report back the government would like to implement on hot topical criminal justice issues.
Whether we are talking about capital punishment, abortion, firearm's issues, violence or about a lot of the more serious community sensitive law issues, there are political sensitivities. Of course it is easier for a government to shrug off independent advice and take advice that follows along in the same ideological rut as that party is in.
I do not bar my own party, the Liberal Party or any other party from that natural near politically instinctive role of trying to head off any kind of serious political heat that is coming toward you, whether it is in the case of someone like Philip Ng in terms of an extradition proceeding or whether it is in relation to some terribly complex and difficult issue such as some of the issues of violence that this House has to deal with in terms of reforming the Criminal Code.
I reject the facile arguments that have been put before the Chamber tonight because I do not think anyone with any interest in the law or anyone who has ever had any association with the Law Reform Commission would buy it for a moment, but the justice committee is going to do it because there is no work plan, there has been no suggestion in the committee. The chair has not come to our critic. There has been no money put forward. There have been no researchers hired. The library of the Law Reform Commission was not sent over to the justice committee so they could set up this body and start doing it.
I think it is disreputable and dishonest to try to bull the public on these kinds of issues that have significance over time. We have one of the highest rates of incarceration in the western world. We have some endemic and epidemic problems within the justice system. There are very high levels of incarceration of aboriginal people. There is extraordinarily unusual sentencing procedures

Government Orders
that affect people of certain income levels, backgrounds, education and employment opportunities.
I used to write pre-sentence reports for a living. I used to be a parole officer on contract to the National Parole Service. I was a full-time probation officer and family court counsellor.
I look back on it with interest. I know the problems that were endemic then and I look at the problems of now. Whether it is the Young Offenders Act or the Criminal Code, this Chamber has enormous difficulty in ever even getting these issues before the House, past the minister, through the bureaucracy, past cabinet and so on.
Having had one of the independent arms of serious analysis cut off in such a cavalier way leaves me with a chilly feeling about what is the real agenda. This is not an expensive operation. This is about five minutes of interest on the national debt.
I looked through the Auditor General's report. I listened to the member for Mississauga South going on about why it was great to get rid of the Economic Council of Canada; that it was too expensive; that we should dump this one in the trash barrel, get it out there into the landfill and bury it over; and that we could not have these things lurking around.
The bodies giving independent advice that the government did not want to heed or found embarrassing have found their way to the trash can. In a democracy that is a frightening revelation of a government afraid of accurate research, afraid of any kind of independent academic or intellectual evaluation over time.
What is the government afraid of? Does its ideological paranoia of Presto and the Reform Party go so far as to say: "When we go into the election campaign we need at least 30 organizations that we have dumped or cut their budgets in the last six months"? That is how we will take on Presto.
The jaw that walks like a man does not need to have these kinds of phoney excuses: "Oh, we are going to give it to the justice committee". Government members should be forthright, come forward and tell the truth about why these are being cut.
The Law Reform Commission is being cut because they did not want to take its advice. In a complex democracy we need these kinds of independent bodies because they act like the canary in the mine; they act like the bell on the deck of a ship. This body has done a lot of important work. It was nationally recognized and respected. It was internationally recognized and respected for the work it was doing for this Parliament and for the people of Canada.
No member on the government side should callously say that there is a body of this Parliament that will take it on, because that is not true. The government should admit that many of the difficult legal issues that come up will now regrettably have to be farmed out to big, overcharging law firms. We will never get this kind of broad, reasonable cost research and delivery of product from private sector firms. It has not happened in the past and it will not happen now.
I urge the member for Mississauga South and others to read the Auditor General's report. If they are looking for areas to cut, they should look within their own incompetence and neglect of departmental budgets which have been occurring for the last eight years under their administration.

Mr. Speaker, this section of amendments deals with the Science Council. I wonder if I could have Your Honour's permission and the permission of the House to permit my colleague who is responsible for our science and technology policy to speak to the motion.
Let's hear your pearls of wisdom.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate my colleague giving me the opportunity to speak to the issue of the abolition of the Science Council. I am especially pleased by the enthusiasm expressed on the other side of the House to hear this intervention.
The hon. member for Edmonton-Strathcona is not in the House at present, but I do appreciate his reference to what he described as my eloquent interventions in favour of committee reform. However, he has had a complete misapprehension of my opinion about how parliamentary reform can be translated into the work of committees.
I would like to use the example of the committee on industry, science and technology vis-a-vis the issue of the abolition of the Science Council to demonstrate how vacuous, empty and unproductive is the proposal that committees such as that replace institutions such as the Science Council.
I would like to point out this is a committee that started out with a great deal of optimism about the capacity of well informed and interested parliamentarians to engage in research, discussion, debate and reflection on issues such as the issue of science policy in Canada. We had a good start.
One of the unfortunate truths of the present Parliament is that as soon as that committee with its members from all three parties began to reflect seriously on the failures of government policy with respect to science and technology and research and development, the committee has been hijacked by those who absolutely refuse any

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
engagement that would precipitate any kind of criticism of government policy.
There is no use our looking to committees to get the kind of reflection at arm's length and independent of government views that this country so badly needs. There is no use looking to the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology which is allowed to speak only directly to the Prime Minister whose reports may occasionally be sneaked out of the library. Science policy cannot on an arm's length basis be gained from the Department of Industry, Science and Technology. It carries out the job, it administers, it overrules the endeavours of government and relate to what is going on in industry.
In terms of an independent, objective examination, such as has been provided by the Science Council, not only of science and technology policy in this country, but also of scientific, technological and industrial success related to technology, only the Science Council has and can provide it.
This institution was established some 25 years ago. There has been so much attention to the cost of these bodies that are being abolished in this bill, I should point out that the Science Council has a budget of $3.2 million. Yes, you heard me correctly, Mr. Speaker, $3.2 million. A piddling sum, particularly at this time to spend on having the government and the people of Canada, I will repeat that, not just the government but the people of Canada, provided with advice that will have an impact on Canada's capacity to make the kinds of decisions, both government decisions and otherwise, that are necessary for Canada to compete in the new global economy.
We hear a great deal about the new global economy. What characterizes the new global economy are the importance of knowledge, the importance of science, the importance of technology, the importance of innovation in economic success for any nation.
If there was a necessity to demonstrate the need for good science policy and changes in science policy in this country, all one has to do is look at the performance of this government since it came into office in 1984.
On the basis of every objective criteria, not only has Canada failed to advance in its relative position with
respect to research and development and technology, it has also fallen behind. There has not been one single net increase in the devotion of resources by this country to improving the scientific condition of this country needed to advance our industrial and economic growth, not one.
Of course, one of the problems with the Science Council is that it recognized that. It said so. One of the things that occurs to me about the execution of all of these institutions is that old legend about the monarch who, displeased with his advisers, said: "Off with their heads". This is what has happened here. The Economic Council disappointed, off with its head; the Science Council dared to criticize, off with its head; the Law Reform Commission dared to be critical, off with its head.
A very important Canadian had something to say about this. John Polanyi, the Nobel prize winner, expressed it this way: "In our concern that the size of the ship is too big, we are removing the rudder". At a time when we need, desperately need, the work of the Science Council, off with its head. Buried completely.
For the information of those across the aisle who look so mystified, let us give them a few examples of the things in which the Science Council was engaged. It was in the process of doing studies of 15 of Canada's industrial sectors in respect to their research and development performance. It was looking at the role of women in science. It has looked at the environment. It has looked at science in the north. It has looked at community economic development. That is a study which has been only slightly recognized. It is a veiy important series of studies and fora in the municipalities in this country which relates to how one goes about generating new jobs, new industries, and bringing about economic development in a sieve.
The council looked at biotechnology. It looked at education. It looked at a whole host of things which were necessary to straighten out if we were going to come to grips with the need for new science, new technology, and new innovation, and real high value industrial growth and economic growth in this country.
Now we are left with one of our most prestigious institutions eliminated. We are left with a government that remains rudderless. As my colleague has said, it has eliminated the Science Council and the Economic Coun-

cil and it is inventing things like the prosperity council out of the prosperity initiative.
I would like to quote the words of a member of Parliament to whom I am very close and who summarized this very well. This is in reference to those who attempted to convince the government that its decision was wrong-headed. It goes as follows: "No matter how little support there may be for the elimination of the Science Council or the Economic Council or other bodies that were eliminated, and how little justification there might have been for the government to carry out these executions, you are likely going to find what too many Canadians have found: No matter how legitimate the claim, no matter how perfect the point of view, no matter how important what it is you have to say for the guidance of this government, it will be ignored. Your head will be cut off".
That is one of the reasons we have such disrespect and cynicism about politics. It is because the democratic process is not working. It cannot work if the government continues to disregard not only the voices of the people but also the voices of those who know more than this government is capable of understanding and whose advice is rejected. It is advice that would be in the interests of Canadians at a time when, particularly in science and technology and research and development, we so badly need a voice that is listened to.
This government is condemned by its actions. It will be condemned by the people. It will be condemned by those who continue to lose jobs and who continue to fear losing their jobs because this government is too stupid to know that it is stupid and that it needs advice.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will not speak long but I do want to respond to one of the comments that the member made. He spoke quite forcefully about the need to make sure we are prepared to participate in the new world economy. I take it he does mean the new world economy and I agree with him. We need to and for that we need up-to-date technology and up-to-date industry to be able to compete.
Government Orders
I understand from him and his party that they are opposed to the free trade agreement. They are opposed to NAFTA. Yet they want to be part of the whole new world trading arrangement.
Maybe he wants to have an updated technology and an updated manufacturing sector to make sure that our inventory shelves are all stocked up, but we are not trading with anyone if we are not trading with the United States and with Mexico. We will have a surplus that we cannot handle because most of our trade is with the United States and hopefully our trade will build with Mexico.
Surely one of these days members of that party are going to have to get it together. If they want to have an updated technology, an updated market and an updated industrial sector, I guess it is not unfair to ask if they want to sell a product. If they want to sell it, to whom do they want to sell it? Maybe the best customers would be the United States and perhaps even Mexico.
If he wants to have a world trading economy and he wants Canada to be part of it and he thinks that the national science council is important to it, that is fine. Then he also has to agree that it would be best to build the kind of trading arrangements that would enable us to sell those products and to deal with disputes, if there are trading disputes between those two countries. Sooner or later they will have to get together and come to a conclusion.

Mr. Speaker, the words of the last member who spoke from the government side of the House put in stark relief the difference between members of that side and members on our side. To him the major problem is, who do we trade with, where do we get the markets.
This has never been the problem. The problem is what do we trade with. This is represented today by one of the most shocking statistics about our current economic plight.
Today we have a $15 billion trade deficit in high-tech goods. This deficit is increasing every year. It means that we do not have the capability of producing the modem, technologically sophisticated goods that this world is demanding.

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
Small wonder that our standard of living is sinking. Small wonder that in two years our ability to compete, according to the World Economic Forum, has fallen from fourth to eleventh position.
What is the reason for this? The world community has condemned our economic performance on the basis that we do not have the technology. We do not have the science. We do not know how to obtain it. We do not have a science culture, a technology culture. We are not educating our people in these areas. We are not training them in these areas. We do not know how to obtain it from elsewhere and apply it to Canadian production.
If we are going to compete in this global community, it is incumbent upon us to make sure that we have the goods and services that the world demands. They are no longer demanding our abundance, our natural resources. That is a very competitive market. The advantage we had from our natural resources no longer brings us wealth. We are going to have to create it out of our heads, out of our human resources, out of our minds and our efforts and our talents. This is a challenge for our young people, to adapt to that new global requisite for creating wealth. What has this government done?
In 1984 the Prime Minister promised that we would double research and development. We started to approximate world standards. From 1984, when we had 1.4 per cent of our gross domestic product invested in R and D, we are now at 1.3 per cent. We are going backwards.
Our competitiveness, our ability to compete is declining annually. Our high-tech trade deficit is going up. We are in trouble. What has this government's response been? As the member said, and I take it at face value, its major economic thrust was to get us into the new markets of the world, but it never found out what it was going to be with. It was not going to be with the goods that created the jobs and the value added here in Canada. Why else since free trade would we have lost
375,000	or 18 per cent of all our manufacturing jobs?
It is because of its free trade policy, combined with its obsession with inflation rather than dealing with the fundamentals of what make a competitive economy in the goods and services that we are going to have to trade.
Today, in this bill, we are asked to perform the final rites for the burial service for the Science Council of Canada, an institution which this government killed off some months ago. The Science Council of Canada was doing more work than any other body in this country to deal with the questions of technology, developing a science mentality in Canada, getting our younger people interested in science, transfer of technology, ways to diffuse it throughout our economy. It had done more work in this area than any other body and it cost us only $3.2 million a year. The $3.2 million is a lot of money, but not when we consider that it had some 25 of Canada's best professionals on its staff, not when we consider that the prosperity agenda of this government cost us seven times that. What did it produce? Yes, some good recommendations, a few pages, but not the volume of detail, scientific and economic research into science and technology. Where is this government's priority?
Why would the government kill off a body which, it admits, was doing work that was critical to our future? Our government pays lip service to science and technology, saying we need to have more of it, meanwhile cutting its commitment to science and technology.
Just look at its cuts to bodies such as the NRC. Look at the way it cut out completely the Economic Council of Canada. What happened? The government abolished the Science Council of Canada, not because it was not living up to what the government hypocritically is saying Canada's future needs, but because that Science Council was the only body, through its chairperson, Janet Halli-well, to say: "Government, you must not be cutting back, particularly when you are saying that Canada should be increasing in these areas". That person had the temerity to criticize publicly the government, unlike other persons who have come before our industry committee in the past, such as Mr. Perron from the NRC who said, no, he would never as the head of the major research body in Canada have the temerity to criticize the government; oh, no, that was not his role. The government could keep cutting as much as it wanted. Janet Halliwell had the guts to tell it the way it was. What happened? Today we are here to perform the final rites on Janet Halliwell and the Science Council of Canada.
November 25, 1992

Let me say one more thing. Not only is this government hypocritical, ill-informed and misdirected in what it has been doing in terms of science policy, it is continuing to pervert this process. When the government a few months ago abolished the Science Council of Canada, killed it, the industry committee, the standing committee of this House, through the opposition members, said we should at least have the Science Council here to have a report on what it has done, what it has accomplished and to get the benefit of its wisdom, even though it is no longer here, as to what we should be doing in the future.
Would the government House leader allow that Science Council to at least impart its wisdom to a committee consisting of all members of this House? No. Absolutely not. The Whips were on. This government was too embarrassed to have any more publicity on this shameful issue. At least the finance committee was able to get the Economic Council before it.
Let us not continue with the approach being adopted by the government. It is trying to throttle debate on Bill C-91, the drug bill, when all we want to do is have witnesses who can tell us whether its drug policies are working as it promised. The government is afraid to have the light of day shed on what its measures entail. It is so ashamed of its acts of cutting the Science Council, of trying to change the drug legislation through Bill C-91, that it is trying to scupper debate. It knows when the Canadian public hears these witnesses, they will rise up in further rebellion against the economic mismanagement, economic incompetence and the totally dictatorial and misdirected attitudes of this government.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to say a few words on this motion. I am not someone who would claim to be particularly familiar with the Science Council of Canada, but I recall that two or three years ago there was a gentlemen from Edmonton by the name of Ron Grantham, a distinguished engineer, principal in major engineering firm in western Canada, well known person in the community who was appointed to the board of the Science Council.
Government Orders
I recall seeing a letter he wrote after a period of time on the board. I believe it was addressed to either the Prime Minister or the minister-I received a copy of it-where he suggested that the Science Council was simply redundant, duplicating what was being done otherwise, and generally his recommendation as a board member was that it should be abolished. I was quick to contact him after the announcement and let him know that he was now out of a job which he, frankly, was glad to hear.
The mandate of the Science Council was to assess Canada's scientific and technological resources and requirements and to increase public awareness of science and technology issues. It had 30 council members, supported by a staff of 29 and a budget of a little over $3 million a year.
When the council was established in 1966 there were no other forums to provide independent advice on science and technology issues. However, with the establishment of many other institutes and centres of research and science and technology there are now many sources of information and advice available on those issues.
Clearly, government spending must be examined to increase its efficiency and effectiveness. In particular, resources in support of science must be rationalized to target research and minimize overhead. The closure of the Science Council will accomplish this with savings of $3.1 million annually starting in 1993-94.
The Science Council and the Department of Industry, Science and Technology have prepared a wind-up plan to predict Canadian taxpayers' investment in the council's assets, to prepare a fair, humane, severance package for its employees, and to outline its intentions for work in progress.
Almost all the work in progress at the time of the February budget announcement has now been completed. Furthermore, Industry, Science and Technology has assumed responsibility for printing and distributing final publications to the public once the council becomes dormant.
The National Library, pursuant to the National Library Act, has arranged for reassignment of the Science Council's library collections, and archival collections have been handed over to the National Archives as per the National Archives Act.

Government Orders
To conclude, the decision to close the Science Council was the right one as it achieves fiscal savings, rationalizes the government portfolio departments and agencies and redirects science resources from overhead to researchers.

Mr. Speaker, I am glad to have an opportunity to speak on the Science Council because it is a body of which this government and this Parliament was and still is in great need.
I think of the words of Canada's Nobel Prize laureate, John Polanyi, where he said: "In our concern that the size of the ship of state is too big, we are removing the rudder."
We are not talking about a great deal of money. We are talking about $3.2 million. I know the member who just spoke said he was not too familiar with the Science Council of Canada. He is probably not aware that it was wrapped up in July. They are not actually working on a wind-up plan now but shut its doors a number of months ago.
In speaking of Nobel Prize winners, I am reminded that two days ago, 1,600 scientists representing almost every country in the world, 100 of them Nobel Prize winners, held a press conference and warned all of the government's of the world of the impending dangers of ozone depletion, in part because of the meeting going on in Copenhagen where our Minister of Environment is at the moment.
They have come to a new conclusion, one that I think Parliaments such as ours needs to take a look at. A body like the Science Council of Canada would have borne the message to this Chamber, to the Prime Minister and to the cabinet. These scientists have come to some conclusions over the combining effects of ozone depleting substances over the Arctic; this is over northern Canada. When you get carbon dioxide into these super cold air masses higher up above the Arctic, the super chilled carbon dioxide does the same ozone depleting as do CFCs and halons and all of these other substances that we have heard about. These 1,600 doctorate level scientists world-wide are now predicting that the ozone will disappear entirely over the Canadian Arctic.
It seems to me that this is the kind of thing that should be debated in this Chamber. Perhaps it is not because as David Suzuki discovered when he provided a questionnaire to a sampling of this Parliament, he discovered that the average level of comprehension on science issues is grade 4. My son is in grade 5. He is 10 years old and he has a higher level of comprehension than the majority of members of this Chamber. I do not denigrate the Chamber for that. Individual constituencies elect members from many different backgrounds. But one of the things that members of this House have not been doing and should be doing is regularly reading scientific periodicals and getting briefings from independent bodies like the Science Council of Canada.
It is just beyond me. This government likes to practise what I call voodoo economics, and this is an example of a book-burning mentality. The Science Council made a number of recommendations on research and development; that we should be going forward on R and D from 1.4 per cent forward and yet under this government we have been going from 1.4 per cent of our GNP backwards. When recommendations saying: "If you are going to get anywhere, you are going to have to get some serious financing into the science community; you are going to have to start going on some of these high-tech ventures and high-tech products, and you have got to have a skilled, trained work force and a skilled, trained academic work force which is capable of staying at the cutting edge." We are not doing that, Mr. Speaker.
We heard my friend from Surrey-White Rock talking about the issue of the Science Council and the expenditures, the need to save money. We heard from the member for Mississauga South saying that we need smaller government, not bigger government. That is no longer the debate in this country or in the world. What we need is better government. We need reasonably intelligent and reasonably well-educated and reasonably with-it people who are involved in the process of governance, in the Public Service and in the work force.
I am appalled. Of the 295 members in this House, there is only a handful who could pass a grade 5 exam on what the depletion of the ozone is all about, who could really tell you what sustainable development is, who could tell you why there are 70 endangered species in Canada, who could tell you why it is important to protect 12 per cent of the endangered spaces in this country.

How do you know, did you run tests of members of the House?
November 25, 1992

Tests have been done. Yes, a test has been done, and the average level of comprehension on science issues is grade 4.
There is 39 or maybe it is 49 members of the cabinet. Most of the members on the government side, at any rate, are in the cabinet so we know the average comprehension level in the cabinet is grade 4 or less on science issues.
We have book burning. Right? That is what you do when you do not like advice coming from people who are educated, you bum the books and you shut them up. Get a big sock and jam it in the mouth of those members of the Science Council. For God's sake, do not let them tell you that there are serious issues out there; do not let them talk about Great Lakes water quality, long chain organo-chlorines; do not let them talk about the problems of plutonium; do not let them talk about what is going on in the atmosphere. Just stick in there and worry about the bottom line. Make sure you get lots of ink-with this government it does not seem to matter whether it is red or black, just make sure you have lots of ink.
It's all red.

It's all red. We have never had it this bad.
Let us compare, Mr. Speaker. The cabinet, these experts on science, decides to buy $4.4 billion worth of helicopters. Then it says: "We are going to put them on our new frigates. We have 10 ordered and we have had one delivered", but the helicopters have too wide a swath to land on the frigates. So it says: "Well, we bought them anyway; we'll use them for search and rescue". Out go the cabinet, riding across the land saying "We bought these for search and rescue".
I have talked to the search and rescue guys who actually jump out of helicopters to rescue people off mountains, out of the ocean and from sinking boats. They say that you cannot perform search and rescue out of the new EH-101's because the down-wash is 160 miles per hour. It would blow their eyeballs out on the pavement.
They cannot get away with that. They have 50 helicopters. They cannot land on the frigates so they cannot go offshore, they cannot chase subs, they cannot go out and check on the fishing fleet because they cannot cany
Government Orders
enough fuel to go out, and they cannot conduct search and rescue missions because the down-wash is too strong.
It is like the subs. This is the same cabinet that was going to buy 10 or 20 nuclear subs and keep them under the Arctic ice to count polar bear tracks. We need the Science Council of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, speaking about significant down-drafts I want to address one more item in this bill. I want to note that we are dealing with a number of sections involving the dissolution of the Science Council of Canada. Clause 36 says:
The council is hereby dissolved.
I want to point out that this section is not yet passed. That is what we are debating here.
Subclause 3 of clause 37 reads:
The minister may do and perform all acts and things necessary for
and incidental to closing out the affairs of the council.
Today my office attempted to reach the Science Council of Canada, which is still not dissolved. The minister has not been given the authority to close out the affairs of the council. We found that neither Bell Canada nor the government operator had a listing for the Science Council of Canada. By dialing both of the old numbers we found that the numbers had been disconnected. When my office called the general inquiries number at Industry, Science and Technology we were advised that "the council has been shut down and no longer exists".
Why are we here? Why are we debating the dissolution of the Science Council if the minister's department is saying that it no longer exists? Why are we authorizing the minister to do things when he has already done them? Could it be that he has done them without authority? Someone from the other side has to explain this in this continuing debate. Help us out a little bit on this question.

Maybe the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, who has a Ph.D. in aeronautics, might understand a little bit. Maybe the government House leader, who has a Ph.D. in chemical engineering, might understand. Who knows?

In many ways it is not a bill that we really expect to see change because, as the representative from the Liberal Party has pointed out, these institutions have already been wound up despite the fact that we on this side of the House have not had a chance to debate even the report stage of this bill in the House of Commons. The reality is that this government has not respected Parliament on this issue. This government has simply ploughed ahead despite the fact that Parliament passed acts in the past to establish these institutions. Now these institutions no longer effectively exist, despite the fact that these acts are still on the books.
This is as clear a demonstration as you could possibly want of the contempt for democracy which infects this Conservative Party, a contempt for democracy which leads this party to continue to hold office despite the fact that the Prime Minister of the country stated before he was elected that there should be an election every four years. Yet this government stays in power despite the fact that it has been well over four years, five days or four days over. It has been over four years and there is no prospect that this government has any intention of facing the people within the foreseeable future.
November 25, 1992

The Prime Minister has stated that he will probably be thinking about an election next August. That also shows the contempt of this party in power, as far as the democratic process is concerned.
The reality is that six institutions are being eliminated by this bill, including the Advisory Council. There are six institutions being eliminated and at the same time a prosperity report is being brought in by this government to establish six new institutions which I am certain will cost far more than these six that are being eliminated. The difference will be that these new institutions will be she new sources for Conservative patronage, six new chances to put people into positions at the public trough before these people are booted out of office. This is not the way a decent, democratic government in this country should run. A decent, democratic government in this country should have resigned after the referendum defeat of October 26. A decent, democratic government should now be facing the people. They should be facing the people. They should be receiving all the portents of defeat which are certain to face them no matter when they face the people.
They can delay. They can put it off. However, they have a date with the guillotine and that guillotine is going to come down. It is going to be, as some of them tried to suggest during debate the other night, a chop-chop ending to this government. This is an ending which is deserved, an ending which is long overdue, an ending which we will help to bring about, an ending which will, in the end, lead to their replacement by a social democratic government that will put into effect a decent, democratic government that will serve the people in this country. It will be a decent, democratic government which responds to the needs of the country and is not interested in simply establishing patronage positions. It will be a decent, democratic government that will act in an honest, straightforward way instead of trying to hoodwink people as this government is trying to do by eliminating six institutions so it can set up six more that will cost this country even more in the future. Let us throw these people out as fast as we possibly can.

What we are talking about in this bill is an attempt-
Don't count on it.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member says: "Don't count on it". I say call an election. We will find out. I urge him to look at the polls. At 14 per cent they have big trouble.
I want to say that the bill before us has chopped six venerable institutions in Canada. The amendment we are faced with tonight is one that deals with a date on which this act is to come into force. It is clause 46 of the bill.
I am disappointed in the amendments that have been moved, frankly. Had I realized the amendments were so brief in their import, I would have moved ones that were a little longer myself. The hon. member for Essex- Windsor was prepared to let this bill come into force on July 1, 1994. Why 1994 for heaven's sake? It is only two years away. It is ridiculous.
I would have put this off for 15 years. Why would we ever agree to a bill that came into force that chopped all these agencies right away? As my good and learned colleague from Scarborough-Rouge River has said, the

Government Orders
government has implemented this bill before we even started debating it.
It chopped the Science Council of Canada even before today. The hon. member tried to phone them today and could not get an answer. Where did he phone after that? He called the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology-
He has been proven incompetent. We read the other day in the Auditor General's report how he was letting out contracts of $700,000 without tender to all his Tory fat-cat friends. That is what was going on there.
As for the prosperity initiative, we know who got prosperous as a result of the prosperity initiative. It was a pack of Tories. They were the ones who got prosperous as a result of the prosperity initiative. It has been a total disaster for Canada.
My distinguished colleague from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell asked an intelligent question on this subject the other day and he got absolutely no answer whatever from the government. I am not surprised.
If the government is prepared to chop the Science Council and the Economic Council because it does not like their advice, clearly it is prepared to do anything and to go to any length to make sure that it does not suffer at the hands of the electorate. The best way to do that is to give good contracts to your fat-cat Tory friends who will give you back the money in spades and campaign donations. That is what we see going on right now. That is what is going on in this country at this moment.
The hon. member looks shocked and pretends he is shocked. He knows perfectly well what is going on. We see it on this side of the House every day. We may point it out. Hon. members opposite laugh. Listen to them laugh now, Mr. Speaker. They laugh. They think that wasting the public funds of Canada on lining the pockets of Tory fat-cats is a good policy or something that they should laugh about.
We on this side are not laughing. We think this is a disaster for this country and the sooner we have an election so that we can get this bunch out the better it will be for all Canadians.
Let us look at this bill. Let us see what the government has done in this bill. The Economic Council of Canada
was headed by a very distinguished economist in recent years, Ms. Judith Maxwell. Queen's University in my constituency has hired Ms. Maxwell to assist them as assistant director of the school of policy studies at Queen's. They have taken her on primarily so that she can complete the very important research that was being done by the Economic Council of Canada before this government announced that it was terminating the Economic Council in the last budget.
It is being done at the expense of Queen's University.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: I believe the Government of Canada is paying some money to complete this research work. Therefore, it is not all at the expense of Queen's University, although I have no doubt the university is picking up some of the cost.
It is patronage in your riding.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
It may be an advantage in the riding. I would not say it is patronage. Normally, when research is done by universities as he must know, universities themselves pick up some of the cost. That cost is being absorbed by Queen's. I have no doubt that it is absorbing some cost in having this done.
Nevertheless, it has the advantage of having the good advice and the instructional capability of Ms. Maxwell whose ability is well known and well recognized across this country because of the excellent work she did for the Economic Council of Canada. Yet the government decided that it did not need this kind of advice. Why not? Because it did not like the advice. That is why not.
The advice was contrary to the rather stupid policies the government has been following in this House which have cost Canadians dearly every day and month of the year. We have paid handsomely for having this government in office.
The questions that were asked by the Leader of the Opposition today and by the member for Windsor West and even the one by the opposition House leader on the Westray situation all indicated a complete and flagrant abuse of the use of public funds in Canada since 1984 and certainly in the last couple of years.
