November 25, 1992

I cannot believe that there are only two minutes left. Have I spoken for eight minutes already? I find this hard to believe.
See how time flies.
It is too long.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
The hon. member says: "It is too long". I can understand his discomfort. I can understand how uncomfortable he feels hearing these true remarks about his government's disastrous record for Canada.
Let us turn to the Law Reform Commission. That is another good one. The Law Reform Commission has provided excellent service to Canadians over the years. I have talked, on second reading of this bill, about when I was in South Africa some months ago with some colleagues from the other side who unfortunately are not here tonight. They have been fleet of foot and I can understand because they must be terribly embarrassed.
In South Africa, we met with a senior representative of their Law Reform Commission. He was not the chairman but he was very senior member of the commission. In the course of our trip, he sat down to a very nice lunch with us to talk about the Law Reform Commission and the work it was doing in South Africa in trying to end apartheid in that country.
His first remark was how much he appreciated the work of the Canadian Law Reform Commission. The reports they received from Canada were among the best in the world. That is what he said. I said: "Well of course". This was in March. The budget came down in February and the government chopped the Law Reform Commission. I said to him: "Well, of course you realize our Law Reform Commission is being terminated". He said: "What?" I said: "Oh yes. In the latest budget the Minister of Finance gave it the chop".
My two colleagues, who are both Tories, good friends of all my hon. friends opposite, went: "Oh no, you would mention that", as though this was something that had gone wrong. Well, it had gone wrong. They realized that their government had failed them badly. Their government had let them down. Their Minister of Finance had done something he should not have done. They knew it
Government Orders
but they are not here to vote against this bill tonight. I bet you they will not be here tomorrow to vote against it either. They were so ashamed. They almost went blue in the face they were so shocked.
If the hon. members opposite had any sense of shame, any sense of decency, they would also stand up and vote against this bill and get this government defeated in this House so that we can have an election and then see who wins. Because if they really believe that what they say is right, if they voted against the government, they might win their own seats. The five or ten that are here might win their own seats and the rest of them can go down to defeat.
The government would be thrown out. We would get a good Liberal government in Canada and Canadians would rejoice. They would rejoice. Canadians would be so pleased that these members had voted their government out they might elect them again.

Mr. Speaker, I truly regret the day the Government of Canada announced it was terminating these institutions. There was one in particular that meant a lot to me and still does, and I am referring to the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
I would like to go back very briefly to April 1984, when, if I remember correctly, we had a debate on second reading of the bill to establish the institute. If I am not mistaken, the bill was referred to the standing committee on external affairs and national defence which I had the privilege of chairing at the time. There were many hurdles to overcome, and I must admit a number of parliamentarians made clever show of ostensibly supporting the bill, because they realized the Trudeau era was drawing to a close and did not want to be accused of preventing the establishment of this important institute. It was important to the people of this world, to Canadian pride, to the young people in our universities and to those who believe that Canada has a major role to play in this area because of our exceptional reputation on the international scene, a reputation I wish Canadians would be more prepared to recognize, because I often notice that foreign nationals take greater pride in Canada than Canadians do themselves. When I say Canadians, I also

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
mean Quebecers, because to me, Canadians include Quebecers.
In 1984 we managed to do the impossible. We were able to report the bill back to the House on June 28, when it was passed. The next day, the Right Hon. Prime Minister at the time, Mr. Trudeau, had the extraordinary kindness to thank the chairman of the committee. I must say I was not in the habit of being thanked by the Right Hon. Mr. Trudeau. Since he assumed I was in the House, he was particularly cordial, but unfortunately I was on the telephone in the lobby, trying to clear up an immigration problem, so I did not hear a word of what he said. I do know that at the time, there were several members like my friend, Stan Darling-even if it is against the Standing Orders to refer to him by name, I will take that liberty-who was involved in those issues, and I am sure he will remember.

The Prime Minister of Canada at that time said: "This is one of the nicest things that happened to me on my last day, the 29th of June, 1984". It was also the last day for the minister of foreign affairs, Allan MacEachen, who announced also that day that he was not going to run again and went to the other place, as we like to call it.
Now, today, the peace institute is disappearing, the pride of Canada, because of a few million dollars.
This institute was created to try to understand the changes in the world. Now the government thinks that communism has exploded, it is finished. Well let me tell you otherwise. This institute would be as important now as it was then to study the world at a very low cost to the taxpayer.
I am known as Mr. Scrooge in my party. I do not like to spend money in a frivolous way. However I have to be on record not because I have given much of my life to that institute, not because with my friend, the hon. member for Parry Sound-Muskoka, we believed at that time that we should have that institute, but it is because of the good that it could still do today.
I am telling you that if I stay in this House longer, if the gods of the day, the ladies who sit in heaven, are kind to me and if I do come back here and if there is a chance, I assure you there will be a reinstitution of a peace institute of that kind.
The world is becoming more and more difficult. Canada has the reputation in the world of being sensitive and understanding. People look to us as a breath of fresh air.

The whole world sees us as a glimmer of hope in an increasingly complex world. People think that if Canada can find some solutions, there may be some hope at the United Nations. The institute analysed all these issues and invited people from all walks of life. You are aware of my support for the Palestinian cause. The institute organized meetings between the people of the country I recognize, the State of Israel, and the people of a country that should exist, which was and will be called Palestine, to try and understand the motivation behind their mutual hostility. I see the hon. member for Outre-mont, a psychologist who knows that if we understand what motivates people, if we understand the motivation behind love and hate, a solution can be found.
The institute provided a dispassionate analysis of the international situation in a world that is changing fast, too fast. We need people with this kind of dispassionate view and an insight, and I admire them. I would like to name all the directors of the institute, but I will name the first one, Mr. Pearson, the son of the man who brought me into politics, Lester B. Pearson, a man of peace, who incidently was the first secretary and the first director general, and the last director, Bernard Wood. No partisan politics here.
Like all the people who wrote to me and whose letters I am still answering, I don't understand. I can find no rational explanation.
I wish to give a rational explanation to people who ask me why it was cancelled. I cannot find one because it was good.
We talk about a new world order. The United States says that there is a new world order. I do not want to live under that kind of definition of new world order. I want-and this is what the Peace Institute was trying to do-more than one superpower in the world. This is known. I want Europe to be one. I want Asia to be one. It is very dangerous if we do not understand the definition of the new world order as defined by the United States of America, our friend and our neighbour but certainly not

my patron or my boss. The Peace Institute was trying to-

-analyse these complex situations.
So I wanted to put this on the record, and I want to thank you, Mr. Speaker, for your kindness and I also want to thank one of the committee's survivors, the hon. member for Pany Sound -Muskoka-

He has been the pillar of the committee on foreign affairs. When everybody was talking nonsense, he was the only one who could come to the committee and say: "That is enough, Mr. Chairman, they are out of order". That would include his own colleagues and at times my own colleagues. I was happy because I felt I had the confidence of my colleagues.
First, I regret. Second, I do not understand. Third, I would hope whoever is in government would reconsider the good that was created by that institute and reconsider the re-establishment of that institute some day. That is why I wanted to be on record.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will not take up too much of the House's time, but this is the first chance I have had since the beginning of this debate to address the termination of these agencies.

It is important for all Canadians to realize just what it is that the government is trying to shut down tonight. When I say trying, I know it will ultimately succeed. It is not that I want it that way but for the time being, albeit temporarily, we still have a majority of Conservative members in Parliament. They want to shut down the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council at a time when issues involving immigration are, shall I say, probably at the top or close to the top of the political agenda of our country.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security is proposed to be shut down. The hon. member for Saint-Denis put the case for retaining that institution so well that there is little I could do to embellish the very good argument he has already put forward.
Government Orders
Turning to the Economic Council of Canada, here we are in the depths of a recession, the worst one we have seen since the great depression of the 1930s by far. There is higher unemployment and the toughest economic situation I have ever had to live with. Yes, I was there in the previous recession of 1982 and in my riding this one regrettably is far worse. At a time when we could be listening to constructive suggestions to get out of the recession, the Economic Council of Canada is all but non-existent save and except a telephone line.
Next is the International Centre for Ocean Development. Last night we were hearing about environmental issues in the Soviet Union. We learned that tonnes of radioactive waste had been dumped in the Arctic for years and none of us knew about it. The new Russian authorities are now making us aware of the environmental disasters created by previous administrations.
On the Law Reform Commission I read a submission some months ago in a newspaper article which indicated that Canada without a Law Reform Commission would be right up there with underdeveloped nations of Africa. I believe the example used was Rwanda. That is now where we are.
I am not a lawyer, not that I apologize for that of course, I want to tell my colleagues over here particularly, but I have read extensively the reports of the Law Reform Commission on a number of issues. I can think right now for instance of the reports it did on such controversial issues as abortion and others, not that I have always agreed with everything that was said. As a matter of fact, I have agreed with dissenting reports but it does not matter. I had good, sound, unbiased information provided by great legal minds that I as a legislator could use. I am not the only one; the courts and others read them. How many people have read reports of the Law Reform Commission? The former Law Clerk of Parliament sat on the Law Reform Commission. I am speaking of Joe Maingot whom you probably know quite well, Mr. Speaker.
We are at a period when we are talking about the future of our country being in research and development. We as a nation are in the process of establishing a space agency. We are debating a bill right now-and I do not happen to agree with the government on its merits- on research issues such as pharmaceutical products. Yet the Science Council of Canada is being abolished, an

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
agency that could give us and give Canadians good and sound advice.
What are we doing it for? I want all Canadians to know that we are doing it to save $22 million a year. I am not saying that is a small amount. That is a lot of money.
Yes.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Now that we have all acknowledged that is a lot of money, including the member for Mississauga South, let me give a few instances of money not so well spent.
I just happen to have a copy of the Auditor General's report tabled in the House yesterday. Let us read a few excerpts from this report. It is quite good stuff. I recommend it. It is good reading.
Let us talk about the industry, science and technology department. We are closing down the Science Council. Presumably there must be some sort of affiliation. The industry, science and technology department entered into 22 contracts worth $3.3 million for such things as advertising and organizing public meetings.
Guess how many of them were correct. Guess how many of them were approved by Treasury Board. Zero. Guess how many contravene Treasury Board regulations. Twenty-two out of twenty-two. Guess how many of those contracts were untendered and went to friends of the government. Twenty-two out of twenty-two.
Let us look at the health and welfare department and its income security programs. This is a cute one.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
I hear the member across the way asking questions. I tell him to be patient. We will enlighten the member. We can even ask him questions later.
The Auditor General is not a member of the opposition, but an independent officer of the House and one appointed by the present Prime Minister, I might add. He said: "The department failed to properly administer contracts valued at $5 million during the planning phase of the Income Security Program redesign project". Let me give you just a bit more information on this, Mr. Speaker, because I know that I have now aroused your curiosity. "While they spent on these contracts, some $350,000 were given in untendered contracts." Do you
know how they did it to give untendered contracts? They broke them down in $10,000 slices and gave a whole bunch of contracts to the same people to contravene the Treasury Board rules. This is what we are told.
I have just enumerated two examples. I could go on and on and tell you about hundreds of millions in government waste. I have just read a few lines in this very thick document.
I say to the members across, if it is $22 million they want to save, why not do some reasonable things like reducing the size of cabinet and having some integrity in contracting procedures? Why is it that this government has no money for these councils, no money to improve the lot of Canadians but it has enough money to renew the lease on a building which the Auditor General says the government does not even need? Why? Why? Those are the questions those members who are heckling right now will have to answer.
They will have to answer to the people of Canada soon. We are into the fifth year of this government's four-year mandate. I hope that they answer very soon.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to give some wind-up remarks on Bill C-63. We saw the government House leader come zinging in here, saying that there were a couple of people in the cabinet who had an education. That is great. I am glad there are. However, one thing the government House leader did not talk about is why the Minister of Employment and Immigration did not have anything to say in this debate to those people who had something to do over the past few years with the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. If it is such a good idea to get rid of it, you would think the minister would want to stand up for it.
Why did the Minister of Justice not come and say something about the demolition of the Law Reform Commission that served this country and this House well for 20 years? What about the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, CUPS as it is known? Where was the Secretary of State for External Affairs? Why did she not having something to say about why this was such a good idea and that the replacement body was where people could find knowledgeable, internationally
November 25, 1992

respected researchers they could communicate with and give their ideas to?
What about the International Centre for Ocean Development? Why did the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans not come and have something to say? Perhaps he could have made some remarks as to the issue that was raised with him so directly in Rio at UNCED on why Canada has not ratified the Law of the Sea, something that is important to countries around this world. We are within a couple of countries of having the necessary numbers for full ratification and yet Canada is still hiding in the weeds.
The Science Council of Canada. What about the minister of science and technology? One would have thought that if the demolition of the Science Council of Canada was so good that surely the minister of science would want to put on the record what these great ideas are for getting rid of it and where scientists are to place their opinions so they can be heard and parliamentarians can find out the independent, collective wisdom of the scientific community.
We do not have that. Here we have the methodology of the book burners. We have the lip-zippers. You do not want anybody talking because they might be talking against your government and you cannot have that.
Of course what it really comes down to is what I describe as the implementation of the flat earth theory from the government benches. It is that these small independent bodies had some influence. They had some power. If we learned anything from the referendum, surely we learned that the collective initiatives of elected members do not have a great deal of influence on certain very important issues in this country. What we should have learned from that is the desire for more local control, more local input, and for these kinds of arm's length institutions where people have some serious feelings that they are going to be heard.
I know lots of peace activists who think the last persons in this country they would ever bother to write to any more, bother to try to call or try to get a meeting with, are the present Minister of National Defence and the present Secretary of State for External Affairs. They know that is a dead end. They do not want to come and play around the skirts or the edges of Parliament. The places they were going, because they knew they were
Government Orders
being heard and they knew they were avenues to the international community were places like the Peace Institute and CUPS. People knew there was good quality research, good quality information. It was a place where they could be heard and it was a place where they knew at least parts of their message would be carried to parliamentarians.
That had to be muzzled. It had to be shut down. I see the bloody fingerprints of political handlers all over this. This was not decided by the Minister of Finance alone. We know something, for example the proposal to put the new immigration operations in Vegreville, Alberta. The government is saying that it is putting it there because it will be better; it is the high-tech age and we have to centralize and to do it all there.
We know enough about computers now. Those 200 people who would be placed in Vegreville could be anywhere. They could be in Iqaluit, Yellowknife, White Horse, Prince Rupert or Toronto. They do not need to be all in the same building, in the same place. Those same political handlers are putting it in Vegreville for crass political reasons. It is the Deputy Prime Minister's seat.
You are nodding Mr. Speaker; you know that. You are a member from Alberta. You know how these things work. You are responding to those vibes from Presto. Presto is saying: "Watch out, Maz" so we have to respond this way or that way; there are too many institutions.
The horrific part of the termination of these particular institutions is the cold, hard, political eye of the handlers. They got their fingers on the jugular of these institutions. The Economic Council of Canada had bad things to say about the government's interest rate policy, its policy on the dollar and what it was doing on research and development. So out comes the hands of the political handlers to strangle it down. They say: "If all you other independent institutions want government funding-see what we did to this one-say nice things about us or you are next".
CUPS says something about something the minister of external affairs does not like and out comes the hand of the handlers. It strangles it down. There is the end of another independent voice. The Science Council of Canada with Nobel laureates gives advice to the Prime Minister and to the country. They say: "There is not enough research and development going on. Canada is

Government Orders
going to start to fall behind". Out comes the arm of the Tory political handlers and strangles it down.
At some point this whole institution, members who can still think, has to say: "What kind of messages are we sending out of here?" This is dictatorial. My colleague is going to enlighten the House on something he knows a great deal about in terms of the entirely undemocratic nature of what is being done here.
These were acts of Parliament. There were votes by every member of this place to initiate them. Their throats were slit. The government treated them like some kind of economic aneurysms. They say: "Give them all a lobotomy. Get rid of these people". Who are these people?
They are not average, run of the mill Canadians, the people who donate their time. I know some of the lawyers who have worked on the Law Reform Commission. They stepped down from the big bucks to donate some of their time, sometimes a few months, sometimes a few years at a time, to move a legal ball forward, back into our court, because they know we kick it out because it is politically sensitive.
It is the same with the Science Council of Canada. Most of these scientists donate their time. I spoke earlier this evening about the 1,600 scientists who two days ago gave an alert to the world. Was is ever debated in this House, that the potential for life on this earth is threatened by something that we are doing? Are we doing anything about it? I think it is one of the problems with this place. There is not a collective, intelligent voice coming out of here any more. I think there was when I came here but we have been battered back, badgered.
We talk about parliamentary reform but every single power that an individual member had when I came here in 1979 has been stripped away. Even private members' bills, what are your chances of ever getting one of serious value voted? You have to win a lottery, then you have to convince a bunch of government members, then if they get a phone call from the government House leader they will not be able to do it. It is preposterous.
The fingerprints of the demands for power are all over this place. It has been corrupted. I think that these are the symptoms of serious corruption and an election could not come soon enough for me. It really could not.
I hear my friends to my right-and frankly I quite often think the Liberals are to the far right of the Tories on many issues, on the FTA and NAFTA. They do not have the moxie to stand up in this House and be honest. They do not believe what the hon. member for Vancouver Quadra said, that they would tear up the FTA. They voted here on May 11 against abrogating. They voted with the Conservatives. It is the same with the North America free trade agreement. In the committee they voted against going to members' constituencies. They voted against going to most of the provinces and the territories of this country.
They do not want the Liberals to be exposed to the reality of their position on NAFTA, that they support NAFTA, they support the free trade agreement. They do not have any plans to change it.
And they have the pomposity to stand up here in the coachman's uniform of the previous speaker and rattle and prattle on about Bob Rae. Bob Rae is a very fine politician. People in this House should have the decency on all sides to say good things about people when they are good. I did that in my constituency and throughout the referendum about the member for Yellowhead. I am proud that I did and I would say it in here any time about someone of that cut of cloth.
I will not say it about the Prime Minister because the Prime Minister did not play fair during the referendum. He knew what he was doing. He knew what he was crafting, and asking in Quebec. That is why the polls are being hidden. We wonder why $3 million in polls are being hidden after the court rules they have to be released. Taxpayers' money was used for partisan political purposes.
It is the same kind of crap in here and it galls me to the bottom of my soul that not a single minister had the guts to come in here and tell the people of Canada why they slit the throats of these independent institutions.
November 25, 1992

Mr. Speaker, to steer us back into the section we proposed, this particular amendment would postpone the implementation and proclamation of this statute for a period that I hope would be a very long time.
What we have behind this bill is an initiative to streamline and privatize and reduce some of the spending. While the expressed motives may be laudatory it is my perception in this case this is not a question of government as in an ordinary privatization of government getting out of business. In this case it is a question of government getting out of government. There is a whole lot of government that has to be done and which, in my view, is not being done. I think Canadians feel that way now.
By cutting these agencies the government says it is going to save some money. The last estimate we heard here on the floor was $22 million. Although the government is cutting these agencies, as my friend from Essex-Windsor said earlier, it has created another six agencies this past year covering the same territory.
I can only note cynically that the creation of these new agencies, or new initiatives, doing things in the same areas happens in the year running up to an election. It is very odd. I resist the urge to be more expressively cynical than that, but the point I am trying to make is that really the government is not saving money here. It says it is, but it is not. It is a very small example, big numbers though.
Just a very few years ago the Law Reform Commission undertook on its own a comprehensive study of the law and reproductive technologies. The cost of that exercise and the report which many MPs have in their offices was $250,000.
Right now a Royal Commission on New Reproductive Technologies is going on and the estimated cost for that-hold on to your hat-is $30 million. On one hand, we have a reproductive technology study costing $30 million and on the other is $250,000. Make the calculation and figure out which was better for the taxpayers.
The Law Reform Commission was better by far. The expertise, all of the information and data was right there in the Law Reform Commission, and it would still be there had the Law Reform Commission stayed.
Government Orders
This government has acted with regard to these agencies without a law to back them up, as I pointed out earlier. I could say that the government was lawless, acting without the benefit of the statute. In any event, it has proceeded and I regret that very much.
The adoption of this amendment would serve Canadians well.
Oh, no.

Mr. Speaker, I have just received the ultimate compliment. The member for Mississauga South said: "Oh, no" when I got up to speak.
I just wanted to make a few comments on this bill. A great deal has already been said that I concur in, particularly by the hon. member for Skeena. However, the one thing that struck me is something that when I first came to this Chamber I would have heard Tories saying, but we do not hear them saying it anymore.
This particular bill has two things in it that augur against the spirit of true parliamentary debate. One, of these various councils, institutes, et cetera that are being shut down, many have been shut down before this bill was even considered by Parliament and passed by Parliament.
I can remember the so-called old days when people would have railed against this usurpation of the power of Parliament. Would it not have been more parliamentary for these institutes and councils to have maintained their existence until such time as there was a real debate in Parliament, and maybe even a debate in Parliament during which members would have been freed to have voted their own particular judgment on this issue because the Science Council of Canada is not a matter of confidence.
We hear a lot of talk about free votes and that sort of thing. Most of these institutions were established by separate acts of Parliament and they should have been disbanded, if they were to be disbanded, by separate acts of Parliament so that we were not greeted as we were tonight with something else that the Tories made a big fuss about many times when they were in opposition, which is basically an omnibus bill.
One time when they were faced with an omnibus energy bill they rang the bells in this place for 16 days and precipitated a parliamentary crisis.

November 25, 1992
Government Orders
Our fundamental objection to this bill is not that it is an omnibus bill. We object to the whole bill. It is not as if there are some parts of it that we want to vote for. It is no wonder people are cynical because the fact is that we see the Conservative Party in government doing time and time again the very things that it made a political and parliamentary career out of criticizing when it was the opposition.
It was good at it. I have to confess I believed the Conservatives. There was a time when I thought they might actually be different in some respects. There was a time when they were different in some respects-very few, very little, not much, but in some respects they were. For instance, there was a time for a while when ministers took the House more seriously. They came in here and made policy statements.
The member for Yellowhead was pretty good at that, and the member for Skeena has already spoken well of him. There were a few others like that, but what have we seen in the last few days? The Prime Minister makes a major economic speech to whom? He made it to the PC Canada fund at $500 a plate.
Here we are. That same day we asked the Prime Minister as representatives of the people, as people who have been elected by the people: "What are you going to do about the economy?" We did not get any answers at all. We were not even told to wait for the evening. We were not even told that anything was going to be said. We had to read about it in the newspaper the next day.
We read about what the $500 a plate people got to know about the Prime Minister's plans that members of Parliament were not told. Just today the Minister of National Revenue outlined a new plan for streamlining Revenue Canada and the collection of taxation in Canada. Did he make it in the House of Commons? Oh, kid me not. Why would you want to do that? Who cares about the House of Commons any more on that side of the House?
He makes a major statement to the Canadian Tax Foundation, and the examples go on and on and on of the systematic contempt in which this government has come to hold Parliament.
There are people on that side of the House who should know better. Some of them are in the Chamber tonight. Some of them would have complained about this
had the Liberals done it and yet we hear nothing. If we hear anything at all, we might hear some kind of sophistic defence of this particular kind of activity on the part of the government.
We have come a long way from those heady days of 1984 and 1985 when there was some reasonable expectation that the great parliamentary reformers would actually act in such a way, through the McGrath committee and so on, as to bring Parliament out of the disrepute into which people thought it had fallen then. I look back on 1984 now as a golden age of Parliament when I compare it to what it is now after eight years of Tory rule. It is after eight years of rule basically not by Parliament, not even by the Cabinet, but by the Prime Minister's Office and by the praetorian guard that gathers now around leaders wherever they are. In some sense this is a function of modern political leadership regardless of party. Here, though, we have its finest example, whereby members of Parliament, the elected representatives of the people, just keep getting more and more marginalized.
It is no wonder that people are mad at politicians. Their anger, however, is in some sense misdirected because they are angiy at the powerlessness of their politicians, of their members of Parliament and of their MLAs. The roles that we collectively used to have, have been eroded by Prime Ministers' offices, by nameless anonymous staff, everywhere you turn. They are making the real decisions in political parties, in the bureaucracy and in the ministries wherever you go. It is eroded by pollsters, eroded by the courts, eroded by federal-provincial conferences and by executive federalism. You name it. There is hardly anything left for members of Parliament to do except to engage in various forms of surrogate political activity.
We fill our days with busyness as a substitute for power. It was not that members of Parliament ever had a lot of power, but they had some and they could make some things happen because this used to be a more human place where making a case to a minister or to some key person might have made a difference on behalf of a constituent or on behalf of an issue.
Look at tonight as we debate the demise of the Canadian Institute for Peace and Security. I was here when that was formed and it was formed out of the concerted effort of a number of members of Parliament on all sides of the House.
November 25, 1992

I think tonight of the former member from New Westminster-Burnaby, Pauline Jewett, who was very instrumental in setting up CUPS. If she were here tonight, the rage that I have expressed and that the member for Skeena has expressed would pale by comparison. That is because there was a recognition at that time that we needed something like the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security to provide independent and objective reflection on a variety of issues.
The end of the cold war does not bring an end to the need for that kind of reflection. In fact, the post-cold war era in many respects might make the cold war look like a picnic if we don't get a handle on the rise of neo-Nazism in Germany and the proliferation of nuclear weapons sold in every comer of the earth by desperate Russians, Kazakhstanis and Uzbekistanis and so on.
We have big problems and the last thing we need is to shut down a think-tank that was trying to give some systematic reflection to these kinds of things. We would not want that, though. Just let the bean counters rule the world. Well, their day will soon be up.
